SVK: 【ttrāyau】 It means ‘I will deliver’ not ‘penetrates’ and is a Late Khotanese spelling for ttrāyū ‹ ttrāyūmā ‹ ttrāyīmä.[Skjærvø,Ⅰ,p.52]

SGS: 【ttrāy-】 ‘to rescue, deliver’ V e act. tr. A ppp. 【ttrāsta-】;3 sg. pres., O.Kh.: 【trāyäte】;3 pl. pres, act., O.Kh.: 【trāyīndä】;2 sg. pf. tr. m., L.Kh.: 【ttrāste】;3 sg. pf. tr. m., O.Kh.: 【trāste】[p.41]

SVK: 【ttremvaśta’】 means ‘he devours’ and is 3 sg. pres. act. from 【ttumalys-】 ‘to devour, swallow’,not ‘beyond trouble’.[Emmerick,Ⅰ,pp.52-53]

DKS: ‘to save’, contamination of 【trāy-】 and 【ttuvāy-】.See also 【trāy-】 and 【ttuvāy-】.
Here 【-au】 may be pronoun, either 【-āṃ】 ‘of us’ or 【-ū】 ‘of you’.

SGS: 【tvaśd-】 ‘to transfer’ VI b act. tr. A/B;3 pl. pres, act., L.Kh.: 【tvaśdīm‹dä›】;2 pl. imper., L.Kh.: 【tva‹śdya›】;【tvaśdyarä】;【ttvaśdyari】[p.41]
【tvāñ-】‘to strengthen’ V e mid. tr. A;3 sg. pres., L.Kh.: 【tvą̄ñä】;3 pl. pres, mid., L.Kh.: 【tvāñāre】;L.Kh. nom. ag.: 【tvą̄ñāka】[p.41]

DKS: ‘vehicle, section of text, canvas of painter’
‘on the canvas’.See 【tvārā-】, with late replacement of 【-e-】 by 【-ī-】

SVK: 【tvyā】is not ‘of them’ but locative plural feminine of the demonstra¬tive pronoun.‘among these’.[Emmerick,Ⅰ,p.53]

SGS: 【tsām-】‘to swallow’ tr. ppp. 【*tsaunda-】;L.Kh. pt. nec.: 【tsą̄mą̄ña】 JP 84V5 KT 1. 169; 【tsāmāña】;3 sg. pf. tr. m., L.Kh.: 【tsodi】.[p.41]

【tsu-】 ‘to go’ I b act. intr. B ppp. 【tsuta-】;1 sg. pres, act., O.Kh.: 【tsīmä】;2 sg. pres., O.Kh.: 【tsai】;3 sg. pres, or opt., O.Kh.: 【tsīyä】;3 pl. pres, act.: O.Kh., 【tsīndi】 Z 2. 135++; L.Kh., 【tsīda】; 1 sg. subj., O.Kh.: 【tsīñi】 ;2 sg. imper., O.Kh.:【 tso 】; 3 sg. inj., O.Kh.: 【tsūta】;O.Kh. pt. nec.: 【tsuñaa-】;O.Kh. ppp. 【tsuta-】, once 【tsva-】; L.Kh. 【tsva-】, 【tsa-】;2 sg. pf. tr. m. (intr.): O.Kh., 【tsutai】;3 sg. pf. tr. m. (intr.), O.Kh.: 【tsute】;3 pl. pf. tr. (intr.): O.Kh., 【tsutāndi】Z 2. 24+; 【tsvāndi】 Z 24. 514; L.Kh., 【tsvāṃdä】;L.Kh. inf.: 【tsai】  ;[p.42]

【thaṃj-】‘to pull’ V e mid. intr. (O.Kh.); act. tr. (L.Kh.) A ppp. 【thīya-】.+loc.1 sg. pres., L.Kh.: 【thaṃjū】.3 sg. pres., O.Kh.: 【thaṃjäte】.3 pl. pres.: O.Kh. mid. intr., 【thaṃjāre】 .L.Kh. act. tr., 【thaṃjīṃdä】.2 sg. pf. tr. m., O.Kh.: 【thīyai】. 3 sg. pf. tr. m., O.Kh.: 【thīye】.O.Kh. inf.: 【thīye】 .[p.42]

SVK: 【thā】 is not a unique verb form but a regular LKh. spelling of the 2 sg. pers. pronoun ‘you’ (= OKh. 【thu】).[Emmerick,Ⅱ,p.51]
【thāna-】 ‘place’ is well known in Khotanese. It is a hybrid based on Prakrit 【thana】 and Sanskrit 【sthāna】.[Emmerick,Ⅰ,p.51]

SGS: 【thurs-】‘to be oppressed’.IV a intr. ppp. 《*》【thursāta-】;【thursäta-】.2 sg. imper., L.Kh.: 【thursa】.3 pl. pf. tr., O.Kh.: 【thursätāndä】.Note also the following: 【thursūṃ】.[p.43]
【thūs-】‘to kindle’ IV a mid. tr. B.3 sg. pres, mid., O.Kh.: 【thūste】.[p.43]
【dajs-】‘to burn’ I b act. tr. (?); mid. intr. B.3 pl. pres, act., O.Kh.:【dajsīndä】.3 sg. pres. mid. intr., L.Kh.: 【daysdi】 .[p.43]

‘to burn’ I b act. tr. (?); mid. intr. B|||3 pl. pres, act., O.Kh.: 【dajsīndä】 Kha 001306. a3 【KT】 5. 125.|||3 sg. pres. mid. intr., L.Kh.: 【daysdi】 Hed. 17. 3, 5, 13, 15, 17 【KT】 4- 3i-|||Et. Av. 【dag-】 ‘urere’, pres. 2 daz̆a- (【AIW】 675); O.Ind. 【dáhati】. Parth. '【wdj- ‹ *ava-dag-】 (Ghilain, p. 51).[p.43]

DKS: ‘to tame’，present 【dīm-】, participle 【danda-】, K 9, 43v4 【aysm‹u›ī dīmāmata】 ‘control of mind’, parallel BS 【cittasya damanam-】
‘to blow,breathe’, participle 【daunda-】, Z 23.160 【śśaṅga damīndä】 ‘they blow the conchs’; Z 19.88 【damäte】 ‘it is blown’;
SGS: ‘to blow’ V a act. tr. A|||3 sg. pres., O.Kh.: 【damäte】 Z 19. 88.|||3 pl. pres. act.: O.Kh., 【damīndä】 Z 23. 160; L.Kh., 【damīda】 P 2928. 33 【KT】 3. 106.|||Et. O.Ir. *【dam-】 ‘blow’ in Av. only in 【dāδmainya-】 ‘sich aufblasend’ (【AIW】 731-2) and 【duz̆dąfǝδrō】 V. 19. 43 ‘qui respire difficilement’ (Benv., 【MO】, xxvi-xxvii, 1932-3, 179-80). O.Ind. 【dhámati】 ‘blows’. Parth. 【dm-】 ‘souffler’ (Ghilain, p. 56); MPe 【dm-】 ‘atmen’ (【Verbum】, p. 173); NP 【damīdan】 ‘to blow’. B. Sogd. has extended *【dmā-】 in δm’s’t ‘swollen’ P 7. 61 (I. G., 【GMS】, § 318, p. 49).[p.43]

DKS: ‘to make’, JS 25v4 【thaṃ vaska dātīnai cirau didai】 ‘you for them made the lamp of the 【dharma-】doctrine’; dedū ‘we made’, Ⅱ 77.17-8 【pvaica masai dedū hūḍai】 ‘we made only a covering to give’ (beside 17 【hūḍāmdū】 ‘we gave’); from participle 【danda-】 to base 【dam-】, see【 padīm-, padanda-】.
‘hold’see 【darra-, dār-, -dāraa-, der-, pader-, haṃdār-】, replaced by 【dṛjs-】.

SVK: ‘thick’|||Bailey’s dara- ‘thick’ does not exist. It is based on a misinterpreta¬tion of two passages from the Si.|||Si 26.55 (151v5—152r3 KT 1.98) describes a remedy for timira (an eye disease), which involves among other things slitting open a chebulic myrobalan (Sanskrit abhayā) to extract the stone and putting in its place a particular preparation. The slit or split made in the myroba¬lan must be covered over with dough before the myrobalan is put in a fire. This process is described in the Khotanese thus: darq hāmai jsa esalyāñä ‘the split must be smeared (digdha-) with dough’. That darq hāmai does not mean ‘thick pap, dough’ is confirmed by Si 26.57 (152r5 KT 1.98), where we find grihqjsa ttū kamalq darq, esalyāñä ‘the severed head (of the snake) must be smeared with clay’.|||The second passage (Si 26.82 = 155v2—3 KT 1.102) is more difficult. Bailey renders darq ysirrā as ‘thick rough’ {Diet. s. v. dara-}, ‘thick, rough’ {Diet. s. v. banaji}, and ‘scraped rough’ {Diet. s. v. ysira-}. However, ‘thick’ and ‘scraped’ are quite different. The latter can be justified by reference to the verb dar- ‘to scrape’ and is in accord with dara- ‘split, severed’ in the passages discussed above. But the meaning ‘thick’ is based on this passage alone. Since the Tibetan version has here ril-gyis stug-po ‘wholly thick’ and not ‘rough’ whereas the Khotanese has ysirrä ‘rough’ it is unsafe to deduce that darq must mean ‘thick’ here only, darq ysirrä may just as well mean ‘cracked (and) rough’, cf. Sanskrit sphutitā used of the tongue disease due to wind in 26.80.|||This dara- ‘split, severed’ is a Late Khotanese spelling of darra- ‘broken’: see below s, v. darra- ‘unbroken’! [Emmerick,Ⅰ, p.54]

‘unbroken’|||Bailey claims that in 【Śgs】 3.14r2 【vysnora kye hamo darrä】 means ‘beings whose bowl is unbroken’ and not as in my edition (p. 47) ‘beings who have a broken vessel’. It is difficult, however, to see how 【darrahamau】 in 【Śgs】 3.14vl could be construed so as to agree with 【balysūñavūysā hvañāre】 ‘they are called Bodhisattvas’. Moreover, since Late Khotanese has 【dara-】 in the sense of ‘split, severed’ (see s. v. 【dara-】 ‘thick’ ！), it is improbable that it should also have 【darra-】 ‘unbroken’.|||It is dangerous to assume that 【darre】 in Z 20.43 should mean ‘held together’ (which Bailey appears to consider synonymous with ‘unbroken’) since more or less everything in these cemetery scenes is broken, torn, split, etc. What about nearby 【darra】 in Z 20.38, 39? In Z 20.39 【darra】 is used of a thread that has been struck. Bailey renders this 【darra】 as ‘torn up’ (【Dict.】 s. w. 【anāskotta, ṣṣonda】), which is similar to my rendering ‘split asunder’. Indeed, wherever there is clear evidence it points to the meaning ‘broken’ rather than ‘unbroken’.|||【darra-】 ‘broken’ can be etymologised easily. It is from *【dṛna-】 and can be compared with Old Indian 【dīrṇa-《1》】 . Bailey’s 【darra-】 ‘unbroken’ on the other hand implies a participle *dṛna- that goes against both Avestan ddrdta- and Old Indian 【dhṛtá-】.[Emmerick,Ⅰ, p.55]

DKS: adjective to a place-name *【darauysa-】, v 209, ooIaI 【darauysāṃ ṣau khrrī dārrjai】 ‘the 【ṣau-】official Khri dorjeof Darauysa’, to Tib.【khri】‘seat’, 【rdo-rj̆e】 ‘BS 【vajra-】', hence for 【vajrāsana-】.
‘ten’, K 43.Ⅰ36 【daśā māśt(a) parsāme jsa】 ‘with the passing of ten months’, =K 40.18 【daśau māśtāṃ jsa.】 See 【dasau】 ‘ten’.
gen. plur. ‘ten’, 11 105*107 【daśaina hāvām】 ‘of ten benefits’ = ibid. 111-2. See 【dasau】 ‘ten’.

SVK: ‘section’ or ‘arrangement’ (Dict.)|||In addition to 【dasa】 ‘thread’, Old Ind. 【daśā-】, Bailey has the entry 【dasa】 ‘section’ or ‘arrangement’. This 【dasa】 is according to him found in two places, once in ApS and once in MPPS (the commentary on the Hṛdayasūtra).[Skjærvø, Ⅱ,p.57]

‘loc. plur. ‘group’|||dastakvā ‘group’ is based on an arbitrary interpretation of P 3510.3.1 [11] 【KBT】 48. There 【ayīṣṭe dastakvā】 ‘I bless with (my) hands’ is closely parallel with 【dastakvā haudvyā ... ayaiṭha】 T bless with both hands’ in 【Deśanā】 78r3 【KBT】 63. In both contexts the expression precedes the 【pūjā-karma】 (act of reverence) and in both contexts the object of the blessing is the Buddhas in the hair-pores.|||【dastaka】 in Z is confined to the hands in the añjali position (2.63 22.188).|||See Stwlia iranica, 9.2, 1980, 189.[Emmerick,Ⅰ, p.55]

DKS: first component, 【dā-gūna-】 ‘fire-coloured’, K 18.193-4 【saramadā-gūna karavīnā bveya harrida】 ‘red, around, rays shine’
see daurmīnai, from *【durma-】, Ⅱ60.17 【dāṃrmīnai ṣkāma dale śau】; Ⅱ77.23 【daurmīnai bagala.】

SGS: ‘to complete, finish’ ? V e act. tr. A ppp. 【*dāśśäta-】|||3 sg. pres., O.Kh.: 【dāśśäte】 Z 10. 26; 【dāśätä】 N 50. 37.|||3 pl. pres, act., L.Kh. 【dāśīde】 Or 11344. 3b4 【KT】 2. 33.|||+ inf.: 【padīde】 Z 23.36; 【naskośä】 N 50.37.|||+pres. pt. (?): 【dāśādūṃ paphūjā】 Hed. 3v6 【KT】 4.23 ‘we have completed collecting’. Cf. 【ākṣuv-】 p.7.|||L.Kh. ppp.【dāśya-, dāśa- ‹ *dāśśäta-\ dāśyā JP】 47v3 【KT】 1. 139 tr. 【samāptta】; 3 sg. pf. tr. m.: 【dāśe】 【JS】 13v1 (55) +inf. 【tsai】; 3 sg. pf. tr. f.: 【dāśā JS】 8r4 (31) +inf. 【hīsä】; 3 pl. pf. tr.: 【dāśāṃdä】 P 3513. 46r1 (Asm. 13).|||Et. H. W. B. cf. Oss. D. 【dāsun, dāst】 ‘heap up; cut’.[p.45]

DKS: ‘may I see’, to base 【dai-】 ‘to see’, Z 2.100 【ma ne dīñi】 ‘may I not see’.
‘seen’ and ‘appearance’, for verbal forms see 【dai-】 ‘to see’;
SVK: ‘seen’ and ‘appearance’ (【Dict.】 158b)|||Bailey reads P 2928 #10 (【LSt】 4c) 【dya vī】 in 【KT】 3.105 and quotes 【dya vī śairka】 in 【Dict.】 150 s.v. da together with Ch 1.002la,a #33 【KT】 2.55 【da śerka】 ‘fine in appearance’, 【JS】 5r3 (16) 【di śirka】, thus giving the impression of understanding 【dya vī】 as containing the postposition 【vī】 ‘in, at, on’ and meaning ‘in appearance’. The impression is confirmed by the fact that he again quotes 【dya vī śairka】 ‘good to look at’ in 【Dict.】 165 s.v. 【dya】 beside 【Mañj】 206 【KBT】 123 【khu tterthyā dya vī】 ‘as in sight of the sectaries’, which is better translated ‘as in the (false) view of the heretics’. However, ‘in the (false) view’ is not the same as ‘in appearance’. A different interpretation is apparently hinted at in 【Dict.】 158 s.v. 【däta-】, where Bailey, after quoting P 3513 #72rl 【KT】 1.248 (【Suv】 [3.83]) '【dya-vīya】 “having a good appearance”, BS 【abhirūpa-】' adds: ‘Also Ⅲ 105.10 【dya-vī śairka】'. Although Degener, 【Suffixe】 309, correctly points out that most instances of LKh. 【-vī】 are not likely to be spellings of the OKh. suffix 【-vīya-】 and that 【dya-v-ī śairka】 in the passage under consideration could be translated ‘sein Aussehen war schön’, I prefer to follow Bailey’s hint and translate 【LSt】 4cd daha' 【pūra dvyavī śairka | uspūryau aidrrā jsa khū *śakax《1》】 as ‘a male child, good-looking, beautiful, with complete senses as Sakra’. In fact, an adjective 【dyavī】 ‘good-looking’ (from 【dya-vīya-】 ‹ OKh. *【däta-vīya-】) is more appropriate in the present context: it is the boy who is endowed 【uspūryau aidrrājsa】 ‘with complete senses’, not its appearance. Degener’s interpretation has possibly been influenced by Bailey’s provisional metrical arrangement that separates daha ’ 【pūra】 and 【dyavī śairka】 in two 【pādas】.|||《1》 For MS ścāka see below s.v.|||[Maggi，Ⅲ，p.75]

‘so much’ (Dict. 158b)|||Under this heading Bailey lists also ‘V 301, 27r2 【dädä ku】', without translation, from 【KV】 15.3 【dädä ku yä】 [ro 【aysmūjna yąnde】 ‘The third (act by which a man obtains birth in hell) is when one [also] performs (it = a great evil deed) with the mind’, Skt. 【tīvrampradusta-cittasya ... -mano- duścaritam】. In fact, OKh. 【dädä】 can only mean ‘third’ (see 【Dict.】 169 s.v. 【drai】). [Maggi，Ⅲ，p.76]

‘stone’ (Diet. 158-159)|||Under this heading Bailey has, among other instances of the word, ‘possibly II 41.10 dädä “stone for mounting (?)’”. The same interpretation is found in 【SDTV】 1.115 and 117 (【'dädä from *dädyä from dädäya-'】). The sentence containing this dädä is Ch 0048 #10 【KT】2.41 【padauysä aśä parauvā va pathāñä dädä spāśāña khu parauva-bara bvä'ttä】 ‘The first horse must be harnessed for the orders there (and) watched until the dispatch-rider mounts’. LKh. 【dädä khu】 means ‘so much that, until’ and 【dädä】 is just a variant spelling of LKh. 【daṃda-】 ‘so much’ (see 【Dict.】 151 s.v. 【daṃda-】 and 158 s.v. 【dida-】).|||Cf. above s.v. 【dida-】[Maggi，Ⅲ，p.76]

SGS: ‘to tame’ V e tr. ppp. danda-|||O.Kh. 【-āmatā】 abstract: 【dīmāmatā-】 Kha 1. 309a1. 43v4 【KBT】 9.|||3 sg. pf. tr. m., O.Kh.: 【dąnde】 Z 24. 273.|||ppp., O.Kh.: 【danda-】 Zb. 20; L.Kh., 【daṃda-】 【JS】17r4 (73).|||Et. ‹ *【damaya-】, cf. O.Ind. 【damáyati】 ‘overpowers’. Cf. H. W. B., 【KT】 4. 163. *【dam-】 is attested in Kh. in the 【-gyā】 abstract: 【daṃgyo Suv】. K. 67r5 【KT】 5. 118 tr. 【damanaṃ】; 【dagye】 ibid. 66r5 【KT】 5. 117 tr.【damana-】(v. H. W. B., 【JRAS】, 1961, 55). O.Ir. *【dam-】, cf. Oss. D. 【domun】 ‘dompter’ (Benv., 【Oss.】, p. 90); Chor.【 δms-】 ‘be tamed’ (W. B. Henning, 【Togan】 Vol., p. 434)[p.45]

SVK: ‘bad’ (【Dict】. 159a)|||Bailey devotes the following entry to this ghostword:|||‘V 301, 27r2 【därä bäśāna yande】 “he acts with evil tongue”; ibid. 27r2-3 【dä‹rä aysmū›na】 “with evil mind”; ibid. 27v3 ‘【dasamä sä kyera dära u‹ysāne jsa?>】 “this is tenth, as much as with evil self’. Possibly 【dire】 in III, 9-10 【dire vā anāspeti paśāñä yem】 “I have sent the bad, the refugeless ones”. See 【dara-】 “bad”. Possibly from 【adara-】 “inferior”’.|||The first three examples are from 【KV】 15.2, 15.3 and 15.10 respectively. The correct readings are: 【KV】 15.2-3 【u śätä ṣä ku yä ro bäśāna yande . dädä ku yä [ro aysmū]na yąnde】 ‘And the second is also when one performs (it, i.e. a great evil deed) with the tongue. The third is [also] when one performs (it) with the mind’, Skt. 【tīvram praduṣṭa-cittasya ...-vāṅ- mano-duścaritam】 (Lévi, 【KV】 44.10); 【KV】 15.10 u 【dasamä ṣä kye atärañ[ī näjsasde]】, Skt 【akr̥tajñatā】 (Lévi, 【KV】 44.11). The fourth example (Balawaste 0154 #9 【KT】 3.131) is a Late Khotanese spelling for 【dīra-】 ‘weak’ (see Emmerick, 【Studies】 1.55-56). See 【KV】 pp.108-109 and 110-111.[Maggi，Ⅲ，p.77]

The meaning ‘bad’ is secondary, the primary meaning being ‘weak’. dīra- ‘weak’ is opposed to 【pata'jsa】 ‘powerful’ in Z 10.2, and it is used dyadically with 【duspäta】 ‘powerless’ in Z 24.270. Hence the derivation of 【dīra- ‹ *dirga ‹ *drigu-】 cf. Avestan 【drigu-】 ‘arm, bedürftig, schwach’, proposed by Henning in 【JRAS】, 1944, 141 n. 7, should not be silently discarded. Moreover, 【dīramggāra-】 ‘evil-doing’ is a rare type of compound with inflection of the first member, which is matched exactly by Buddhist Sogdian 【SryiFnk'r'k】. See on 【śśära-】 ‘good’ below.|||See already 【JRAS】, 1969, 65.[Emmerick,Ⅰ, p.55]|||‘bad’ (【Dict.】 159)|||The phrase 【dīrä (dīra) yan- act】. ‘to cause to be ill’ (not recorded in 【Dict.】) occurs three times in Ch. 00217a-c 【KT】 3.135 (under the signature Stein 117.1-3).《1》 Its meaning is assured by both the context and the corresponding, though not parallel, Chinese text (‘this spirit is the cause of the trouble’, translation by A. Waley, 【A catalogue of paintings recovered from Tun-huang by Sir Aurel Stein】, London 1931, pp. 171 -172) and lends support to the meaning ‘weak’ for 【dīra-】 and to its derivation from OIr. *【drigu-】, cf. Avestan 【drigu-】 ‘arm, bedürftig, schwach’ (see Emmerick, Studies 1.55-56).|||Judging by OKh. 【śśäru yan- act】. ‘to do good’ (【Z】 2《7》+), LKh. 【-ä/-a】 in 【dīrä (dīra) yan-】 is from OKh. 【-u 】‹ OIr. *【-am】. This is confirmed by the fact that the phrases 【dīrä (dīra) yan-】 and 【śśäru yan-】 correspond to the compounds 【Z】 2《69》 【dīram-ggāra-】 ‘evil-doer’ and, respectively, 【Śgs】2.4v2 【śäram-gāra-】 ‘well-doer, friend’ with inflection of the first member (cf. Emmerick, Studies 1.55-56 and 1.117-118).|||Note that a difference is made between 【dīrä (dīra) yan-】 with active verb and the frequent 【dīra kädagāne yan-】 ‘to do evil acts’ with middle verb (cf. Canevascini, ‘Medio-reflexive verbs in Khotanese’, in 【Mac¬Kenzie Fs.】 23-26).|||Cf. 【Studia Iraniea Mesopotamica et Anatolica】, 1, 1994, 67-68. See also s.v. *【dära-】 ‘bad’.|||《1》 The phrase seems to occur also in the unclear sentence 【JP】 47v2 【KT】 1.139 【haṣṭav-ī dīra na īdä】, on which see Emmerick, 【JEĀS】, 2, 1992, 80.[Maggi，Ⅲ，p.77]

【haṃdarai dīśīra】 in Rāma 208 (47) 【KT】 3.74 is rendered by Bailey ‘some were throwing it out’. A more plausible rendering is ‘some were making it burn’: see above s. v. 【gvahan-】.|||【dīś-】 is derived by Bailey from ‘base 【dag-】, with 【dag-ś-y-】 to 【diś-】’ Bailey’s etymology was reported by me in 【SGS】 46. Meantime E. Tichy has shown that 【dīś-】 derives from *【daisaya-】 from IE *【deik̑-】 ‘to throw’ attested also in Greek διϰεϊν ‘to throw’ (【MSS】, 38, 1979, 171—228).[Emmerick,Ⅰ, p.56]
SGS: dīśś-  ‘to throw’ H. W. B., 【BSOS】, viii. 121, 1935. V e tr. ppp. 【dīsta-】|||L.Kh. pt. nec.: 【dīśąñą,, dīśą̄ñä】 Si 153v2 【KT】 1. 100 tr. 【bor】.|||2 sg. pf. tr. m., L.Kh.: 【dīṣṭai】【JS】 6v2 (23); 9v1(36).|||3 sg. pf. tr. m., L.Kh.: 【dīṣṭe】 Ch 00266. 203 【KBT】 29 = 【nīśāve】 P 2957-138【KBT】38. ’ .|||Et. H. W. B., cf. 【daxs̆-】 ‘throw’ in Av. 【fradaxs̆anā】- ‘sling’, 【dīśś-】 is then caus. ‹ inch, of *【dag-】 ‘throw’, and Av. has an 【s-】extension (cf. Av. 【bag-】, 【baxs̆-】, etc.). I. G. draws my attention to B. Sogd. 【’nδyščy】 ‘Verwerfen’, d.i. 【pratikṣepa】 ST, ii. 575 s.v. From a base *dai- (with s-extension in Sogd.), the inch, should be *【dĭs-】. However, all presents of class V e in 【-śś】 have a long vowel in the root syllable.[p.46]

SVK: ‘is put in" (【Dict.】)|||‘Sid. 15r3 【jsä’ñāñä daṃda khu si’ *kaṣā】’ (MS 【cuṣā】’) 【dīṣḍa】 “to be boiled; so much this kaṣaya- decoction is to be poured in” ’ (【Dict.】).|||Bailey proposes to see in 【dīṣḍa】 the 3 sg. pres. mid. form of an unattested present stem *【dīṣṣ-】 ‘from 【dagš-】’. He deduces the meaning from the Tibetan, of which he writes: ‘Tib. 【sman-gyi khu-ba du-nas (hdu】 “combine”; 1. 3 【du-bar byaho = niśāña-】)’. It is not clear, however, why Bailey translates 【dīṣḍa】 as ‘is to be poured in’ in his rendering of the passage quoted, as if 【dīṣḍa】 were a participle of necessity. The rendering given is misleading for a second reason also, 【jṣą̄ñāñä daṃdä khu】 is a common phrase in medical texts and means ‘it is to be boiled until’ or ‘it is to be boiled so much that’. Bailey’s rendering disregards 【khu】 and the general usage of the phrase.[emmerick, Ⅱ , p.59]

SVK:
‘deception’ [not ‘grasping’] [Emmerick, III, p. 79] ||| As the line division of Mañj 40 【KBT】 114—115 indicates, Bailey had not recognised here a word 【drauna】 at the time of editing KBT. It is obscured by the use of punctuation in the middle of the word at its first occurrence: 【drau: na】. However, such punctuation is found in the middle of a word elsewhere in Mañj as at 62 【KBT】 116 【dīragā:ra】 ‘evil-doing’. At its second occurrence it is obscured by the fact that 【drrau】 and 【na】 are not only separated by being on different lines but by the fact that a deleted syllable precedes na. However, a deleted syllable often occurs in the middle of a word in this manuscript e. g. 【āśa’】 30, 【yadrraḍä】31, 【udvīya】 37, 【dasau】 61, etc.
The passage in which 【drauna】 occurs twice was discussed by me in some detail in 【Asia Major】, XVI.1—2, 1971, 63—7. The context was shown to contain a reference to the four deceptions (Buddhist Sanskrit 【viparyāsa《1》】): ‘the mistake of thinking the impermanent to be permanent, the impersonal to be personal, the impure to be pure, unhappiness to be happiness’. Bailey wishes to understand 【tcahau-padya jsīrja-hanāsa】 as ‘the grasp of deceit (= BS 【śāṭhya-grāha-】) is fourfold’. Against this stands the fact that 【hanāsa】 is elsewhere absent: 【tcahau-padya jsīrrjau】 Mañj 57 【KBT】 115 and 【tcahau-padya jsarjau】 Mañj 316 【KBT】 129, and simply 【jsīrjai tcahaure】 Mañj 66 【KBT】 116.|||【uysānā hīvī drauna】 is understood by Bailey to mean ‘through the grasping of the self (= BS 【ātman-】 for 【ātma-bhāva-】 “body”)’, but in fact it means ‘by the deception of the self’, that is, by mistakenly believing that the selfless (【anātman】) is self (【ātman】). [Emmerick, I, p. 58]

Bailey interprets 【dvā̜ñä】 in Si 23.17 (137r5 KT 1.74) as ‘it must be besmeared’. He wishes to separate 【dva-】 ‘smear’ from 【dvya-】 ‘to beat’. The meaning of 【dvā̜ñä】 in Si 20.13 (126v5 KT 1.58) is not in doubt. It corresponds closely to Sanskrit 【tädana-】 and Tibetan 【rdeg-pa】 (see Bailey s. v. 【dvya-】). What reason is there for separating 【dvā̜ñä】 in Si 23.17 from 【dvā̜ñä】 in Si 20.13 ? The absence of 【-y-】 is hardly significant. The 【-y-】 may be secondary in any case (see SGS 44 s. v. *【dav-】), Even if it is not second_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x001f_ary, 【dvā̜ñä】 could easily have been simplified to 【dvyā̜ñä】, In Ch ii.002 it could well be a defective writing of 【dvyā̜ñä】 since such defective spellings abound in that manuscript.|||Si 23.17 concerns the well-known 【śata-dhauta-ghṛta】, Its preparation is not explained in the Sanskrit text, but the Tibetan and Khotanese versions have more detail. Bailey quotes only part of the corresponding Tibetan, which has: 【yaṅ-na mar gźu-źiṅ hkhyag-tu bcug-pa de-lta-bur lan brgyahi bar-du byas-te rul-bar gyur-pahi naṅ-du śiṅ-mṅar-gyi phye-ma śas cher blug-ste sbyar-bas bsku-bar byaho】 ‘alternatively (【vā】), one must beat (【dhautaṃ】) ghee (【sarpir】) and make it congeal, and making it like that a hundred (【śata-】) times, when it has become rancid, one must pour into it in large quantity (【-utkaṭam】) the powder from liquorice (【yaṣṭi- madhu-】), and smear it (over the patient) (【lepanaṃ】)。|||It looks as though the Tibetan rendering provides an interpretation of 【dhauta-】 as ‘beaten’. It is clear that the Khotanese follows the Tibetan in this interpretation and that 【dvā̜ñä】 ‘to be beaten’ corresponds to Tibetan 【gźu-ba】 ‘to strike, to lash’ (Jäschke). 【gźu-ba】 is explained as 【brgyab-pa】 (‘to beat, strike’) by Sumatiratna.|||śata-dhauta-ghṛta in Vāgbhaṭa, Ah., Ci, 18.13 is correctly rendered in Tibetan by 【lan brgyar bkrus-pahi mar 】(Peking 196b4) ‘ghee that has been washed a hundred times’. It is washed with cold water (see VŚS s. v. 【śata-dhauta-ghrtam】; 【Śrīkaṇṭhadatta】 on Vṛ 19.1). It is no doubt beaten up with the cold water rather than ‘besmeared’ with it.  [Emmerik, I, 59]

SVK: In Diet. s.v. 【naṃñä】 Bailey quotes from P 2026 #99 【sumīrä śaśvāṃ naṃñä ttrāyi hatcä tcauryau dvīpyau】, which he translates ‘Sumeru (mountain) (and) the mustard seed he carries away to nothingness to_x001F_gether with the four continents’. His word 【naṃñä】, invented exclusively for this passage, he explains as deriving ‘from 【na-】 “not”, with 【-ṃña-】.|||The interpretation Bailey proposes for this passage does not agree with Buddhist teaching elsewhere. The correct interpretation was already given by me in 【JRAS】, 1967, 25: 【sumīrä śaśvā̜nąñä ttrāyi hatcä tcauryau dvīpyau】 ‘he will deliver Sumeru into the grain of mustard together with the four 【dvīpas】’ With this compare the similar formulation in Ch 1.0021b, a #38-39 【KBT】 151: 【sumīra garä pūsą. ttrāyau śaśvāṃ myā̜ñä bīśī hā baiśnä hatsa tcauryā dvīpyau】 ‘I will completely deliver Mount Sumeru into the middle of a grain of mustard, all of it utterly, together with the four 【dvīpas】’ The loc. sg. 【śaśvā̜nñä】 from 【śśaśvāna-】 ‘mustard grain’ is like 【padānaña】 loc. sg. from 【padāna-】 ‘vessel’ (SGS 262). [Emmerick, III, p.79]

See【 ttrām-】 p. 40. Cf. Av. 【ram-】 ‘ruhen’, pres. 28 【rāmya-】 (AIW 1511); Parth. 【n(y)r’m-】 ‘abaisser, soumettre’ < *【ni-ram-】 (Ghilain, p. 73). [p.49]

SVK: In this entry, Bailey lumps together the three verbs listed in SGS 55 as * 【nirǔj】- ‘to burst; disappear’ ‹ *【ni-ruj-ya-】; *【nirus-】 ‘to burst’ ‹ *【ni- ruxsa-】;  【nirūj-】 ‘to break open’ ‹ *【ni-raujaya-】 (thus Emmerick). What strikes one here is the coexistence of two different, but apparently (partly) synonymous intransitive/passive formations from one and the same root: with 【-ya-】 and 【-sa-】. As far as I can see'that is the case with no other verb in Khotanese. Moreover, *【nirǔj-】 forms a secondary causative *【nirujāñ-】 differing in meaning from the simple 【nirūj-】. Close examination of the use of these verbs, however, reveals that only 【nirūj-】 and *【nirus-】 belong together as transitive and intransitive respectively, meaning ‘to open /be opened forcefully; to break / be broken open’ (not however ‘to break / be broken’ alone), whereas *【nirǔj-】 means ‘to be destroyed, removed’ rendering Skt. nirudhya- ‘to be stopped, cease; to be suppres_x001F_sed, destroyed’, etc. In fact, *【nirǔj-】 is a loanword from Indian, Skt. 【nirudhya-】, Pali 【nirujjha-】, Gandhari Praktrit 【nirujadi】 (Brough p. 302). It is one of the numerous loanwords which do not make their appearance till in Late Khotanese.[Skjsærvø, II, p.65]

SVK: To the forms listed in the entry a hitherto unrecognized 1 sg. pres, form 【naṣphaścū】 is to be added.|||The word occurs in Or. 8212.162.149 KT 2.9. Bailey read 【naṣkaścū】 with fn.4 on 【KT】 2.9 ‘Unusual shape of 【ṣka’】. In 【Saka Documents Text Volume】, London 1968, 28, Bailey translated it ‘a register’ without explanation. The way the scribe of Or. 8212.162.125 ff. 【KT】 2.8—10 (facsimile in 【Saka Documents I】, London 1960, plates XII—XIII) writes the 【akṣara pha】 is that, after making a loop, he does not stop at the horizontal stroke, but goes through it. See e.g. 【pha】 in line 152 (the fourth akṣara from the left). The elements of the ligature 【ṣpha】 are recognizable.|||The context in which this word occurs follows a passage in which the Linggong accuses those men who did not go to China (although they said they would): Or. 8212.162.148—149 【tta ttau hvai sa ttu-v-ā vāsta hūryara】 ‘He ( = the Linggong) said to us as follows: “Give the clothing to them” ’, 149 【u nai hvaḍādū】 ‘And we did not give it’, 149 【u tta ttau hvai sa vañau sa naṣphaścū 】‘And he said to us as follows: “Now I shall just (the second 【sa】 = 【saṃ】) expel them3”’. In this conversation, 【we/us】 is the Khotanese envoys, among whom is the author of this report.【Kumamoto, II, p.71】

Caus. < *【naṣphast-】; N.【phast-】 p. 90. [p.52]

Caus. <【 naṣphan-】 q.v. Cf. Sarīkolī 【nalfon-】 H. W. B., TPS, 1956, 120, n. 3; 【KT】 4. 18. Cf. also 【šughnī nax̌fḗn- 】(I. Zarubin, šugnanskie teksty i slovar’, Moscow, 1960, 185); Rōš. 【nawfēn-】 (V. S. Sokolova, 【Rušanskie i xufskie teksty i slovar’】, Moscow, 1959, 213). [p.52]

SVK: ‘Sid. 138rl 【habistä nasą】, “in contracted amount”, Tib. 【mdor-na】 “in short”’ (Bailey, 【Dict.】).|||【habistä nasą】, in Si 23.25 should be divided and read 【habistäna saṃ】. The instr.-abl. sg. is used adverbially elsewhere e. g. 【ṣi’buri hve śāstārä haṃbi’stäna sūtträ】 (P 2782.57 【KT】 3.61 = id. P 2029.18 【KT】 3.55) trans_x001F_lated by Bailey ‘This great teacher taught the sūtra concisely’ (H. W. Bailey, 【Sad-dharma-puṇḍarīka-sūtra, the summary in Khotan Saka】, Canberra 1971, p. 4). 【saṃ corresponds here to Tibetan kyaṅ】. It similarly corresponds to 【yaṅ】 in Si 20.19 26.24, 84, 90. [Emmerick, I, 61]

‘Sid. 133v5 【cedāma nasta ...】 “thought checked”’ (Bailey, 【Diet.】)|||With this compare Bailey, 【KT】 6.134: ‘Sid. 133v5 【cedāma nastä】 means thought ceased, Tib. 【sems-pa daṅ】 has a lacuna.’|||The assumption of a lacuna in the Tibetan version is quite gratuitous and is not repeated in the 【Dict.】, where the phrase 【cedāma nastä】 is inter_x001F_preted in more or less the same way, although two different new etymologies are proposed for 【nastä】.|||The idea that ‘thought checked’ or ‘thought ceased’ is totally at variance with what medical texts teach concerning the man with a phlegmatic nature. In 【Vāgbhaṭa】, 【Śā】. 3.96 he is described as 【buddhyā yuktaḥ】 ‘mit Einsicht begabt’ and in 【Śa.】 3.101 as 【gambhīraḥ】 ‘tief veran- lagt’. The latter is rendered in Tibetan (Pek. 91b4) as 【blo zab】 ‘(having) deep thoughts’. It is accordingly more likely that 【cedąma nastä】 in Si 22.4 means ‘(his) thought (is) profound’.|||As long as this 【nastä】 remains isolated, however, it must remain suspect. One can for example suspect that the scribe intended to write *【cedą̄mastä】 ‘thoughtful’ (with the 【-asta】 suffix mentioned above s. v. 【chadrasta】) but added 【na】 because he thought of 【cedą̄mana】 ‘cintāmaṇi’.|||On the other hand, there is an unexplained 【nasta】 in Old Khotanese. On possible explanations of 【nasta】 in Śgs see my edition p. 66. In 【Dict.】 s. v. 【nasta bāgyä】 ‘root’ a new explanation is proposed. Bailey explains the expression as being literally ‘end-part’. The idea that 【bāga-】 ‘part’ is to be sought here seems to have been forgotten or abandoned by Bailey by the time he reached the letter b since 【nastā bāgyā】 is listed under 【bāga】 ‘root’, not under 【bāga-】 ‘part, portion’. This 【nasta】 remains obscure to me, but it may be the same 【nasta】 ‘deep’ as may be attested in Si 22.4.[Emmerick, I, p.61]

The rendering ‘are perished’ is not convincing as ‘perished’ is sufficient. We cannot have here the ‘base 【nas-】 “perish”, passive 【nasya-】 with periphrastic 【āya】 (?)’. From *【nasya-】 the expected development is to *【naśś-】 as in 【panaśś-】 ‘to perish’ from *【apa-nas-ya-】 cf. Avestan 【apanasiia-】 (SGS 70).|||Bailey seems to have been misled into thinking that 【nas-】 is here required because in P 2786.196 KT 2.99 he read 【hauvą hänasyąvą】, which he renders ‘the forces exhausted’ and compared this hänasyqvq with 【hanaśś-】 ‘to fail’. However, 【hä】 is probably to be read as 【hā】 and if not it must in any case be emended to it in the light of the second version of the text in Or. 8212.186.33 KT 2.11, which has ] 【ra hā naspava】. There 【naspava】 is a graphic error for *【nasyava】 as noted tentatively by Bailey, KT 2.11 n. 8. That we have here the particle 【hā】 is also confirmed by 【hā hauvä nasyaiyą】 in P 2786.202—203 KT 2.99 = 【hā hauva nayseye】 Or. 8212.186.40 KT 2.11. Incidentally, the above parallels exclude the possibility of dividing the syllables so as to obtain 【hauvana】 ‘powerful’ as Bailey does in KT 2.11.|||The ending 【-aiyą/-eye】 limits the number of possibilities because there are very few verbs conjugated according to my C and D patterns (SGS 177). 【nasyaiyą/nayseye】 points to an Old Khotanese 3sg. present middle *【niysaiye】 from *【ni-zav-】 comparable with Old Khotanese 【buysaiyä】 from *【vi-zav-】 (SGS 101). 【nasyaiyą】 is probably a graphic simplification of *【naysyaiyą】 rather than a mistake for *【naysaiyą】 (cf. 【nayseye】) since the intrusive 【-y-】 is likely to be due to the preverb *【ni】 just as Late Khotanese has buysvaiye for Old Khotanese 【buysaiye】 with a secondary 【-v-】 due to the preverb 【bu-】. For these forms of buysai- see SGS 101.|||The past participle 【nasyąvą】 probably also stands for *【naysyąvą】 for Old Khotanese *【niysuta】. Here of course *【naysyąvą】 is 3sg. perfect intransitive feminine. The 【-ya-】 will be for an earlier 【-ä-】 due to *【ni】, cf. Late Khotanese 【jyava】 Mañj 122KBT 119 = Old Khotanese 【jäta】  Z 23.20.|||【hā hauvä nasyaiyą】 is thus ‘strength fails’ and 【hauvą hā nasyąvą】 ‘strength has failed’, that is, ‘(my) strength is exhausted’.[Emmerick, II, p.71]

DKS: v.l. pai nā ‘he took the cup(?)’

SVK: Read 【ttārä】.|||Bailey’s reading of this word as 【nārä】 in the Amṛta-prabhadhāram 49 (25b8) KT 5.64 is not correct. Close inspection of the akṣara in question on the photographs in the Hamburg collection reveals that it has none of the characteristics of a 【nā】. Comparison of this akṣara with similar or even nearly identical akṣaras in the same manuscripts furthermore indicates that it cannot be 【dā】, 【vā】 or even 【ntā】 (in 23b 10 【aparānta】), and so must be 【ttā】. Cf. (Hamburg photograph nos. in [ ]): 【ttā(rä)】 25b8 [212]; tti 25b7 [212]; 【ttā(rä)】 23b 12 [216]. [Skjsærvø, II, p.73]

W. B., 【BSOAS】, xi. 1, 1943, 3: 【nāte】 P 5538a 39, 40 KT 2. 127; 【nį】 P 2801. 21 KT 3. 66; 【nati Vajr.】 Ⅱb4 【KT】 3. 22 tr. 【udgrahītum】, 【natä】 ibid. 12ai; 【nitä】 ibid. 12a4.|||Et. Cf. Av. nas- ‘hingelangen zu’, pres. 4 【nāsa-】 (【AIW】 1056); O.Ind. 【náśati】 (aor.-subj.); Yaghn. 【nos-】, 【nóta】 ‘take’ (Andreev, p. 295). The ppp. 【nāta-】 is secondary, due to reinterpretation of 【nās-】 as inch, on the analogy of stās-fstäta- etc. That the base is *【nas-】 is shown by the noun 【nasa-】 ‘share’ Z 5. 42, 48; 【Vajr.】 31a2 【KT】 3. 26 tr. 【kalā-】. SVK:
‘humble’(Dict. 187-188; Studies l .62--63)|||
Two further attestations of this word are provided by the new St.Petersburg Suv folios. In SI M 13.6+ 12#r6 【nihala-māna sa-ggaurava】 corresponds to Skt. 【sa-gaurava】 at [ 14.27 ] and in SI M 13.6+ 12#v2 【sa-ggaurava nnihala-māna】 also corresponds to Skt. 【sa-gaurava】 (【SDTV】3.193-194). For the writing of initial 【nn-】 for 【n-】 cf. 【nnaunu】 in 【Z】 3《91》 and see Maggi, 【KV】 p. 91.|||
See 【Gignoux Fs.】 57.|||[Emmerick，III, p.81]

SVK:
‘be attached to’[not‘desire, grasp at’as Dict. 188)|||
Bailey, 【Dict.】 188, gives the meaning‘desire, grasp at’ and elswhere also ‘long for’ (cf. 【SGS】 58,‘to long for; grasp at’), but new bilingual evidence showing that the verb means‘be attached to’ is found in:|||【Anant】 13.3 (【KT】 5.102 no. 201 r3-4) 【ka brīyau vätä ne nähvarrde】‘when he is not attached to passion,’Tib. 【hdod-pa-rnams lḫag-par chags-pa med-pa】 [ = Skt. 【an-adhyavasita】] 【yin】; 《1》|||【Anant】 13.7 (【KT】 5.124 no. 221 b4)【 [hā]vä pajsamä anähvarremäte jsa】‘by non-attachment to profit and honor,’Tib. 【rñed-pa daṅ bkur-sti … -lalḫag-par chags-pa med-pa daṅ】.《2》|||[Skjærvø, III, p.82]

SVK: nä, nu, ne, ni 【‘them, their’, enclitic (Dict.) 】|||‘From *【na-】 pronoun "that", plur. *【nai】. IE Pok. 319 【e-no-, no-,】 Av. 【ana-】... 0. Ind. 【aná-】..．【nā-nā】 "variously", Greek【vaí】 “surely", Lat. 【enim】, 【nam】 "for".’(【Dict】.) |||This etymology is unsatisfactory, if only because none of the proposed cognates listed by Bailey functions as an enclitic pronoun. In most Iranian languages the third person plural enclitic pronoun is formed from the same stem as its third person singular counterpart. Thus, Old Persian has sg.【 -šaiy】: pl.【-šam】, continued in Middle Persian by 【-š: -š’n】, where the pl. form results from a thematicized  *【-šānām】. In the case of Sogdian 【-š(y): -šn】， the plural must be derived from *【-šǎn̄ā̆m】，with secondary shortening of unstressed 【ā】 in a polysyllabic ending (cf. pronominal genitive plurals such as【wyšnw】 < *【awaišanăm, wyspyšnw 】< * 【wispaišănăm】). While these languages have generalized the sandhi-forms with 【š】 (cf. Av.【šē】），others have generalized that with 【h】 (cf. Av. 【hē】), as exemplified by Bactrian 【-ηιo : -avo】, Choresmian 【-hi : -na】, Parachi 【-ē: -an】. All these forms require the reconstruction of a thematic *【-hānām】, with secondary shortening to *【hănā̆m】 at least in Choresmian and Parachi.|||A similar form is to be expected for the third person plural enclitic pronoun in Khotanese in view of the third person singular 【-ī, yä < *-hai】. Accordingly, Khotanese 【nu】 may be derived from *【-hănăm】 (with secondary shortening of both syllables as in the thematic genitive-dative plural ending 【-änu】 beside 【-ānu】, cf.【SGS】267），while the more common spellings 【nä】 and 【ni】 may show the influence of the other enclitic pronouns, most of which end in 【-ä < *-ai】 or *【-ah (mä, tä, yä, nä < *-mai, *-tai, *-hai, *-nah】). |||[Sims-Williams, II, p.74]

‘Sid. 138r5 【neca hame】, BS 【nimno】, Tib. 【hdug-pa】 "seated", hence for older 【neʼsta-ʼ】(Bailey, 【Dict】.) |||Si 24.2 (138r5 【KT】 1.76) concerns swelling due to wind. It is charac­teristic of this swelling that【gar mnan-pahi mal śoṅ der hdug-pa】‘the place where it is pressed (【pīḍanān】) remains in that hole (【nimno】)’. The Derge blockprint has【śoṅ】 ‘hole’ whereas the Narthang and Peking blockprints have 【śod】 ‘lower part’. The variation hardly affects the meaning. However, 【der】must be read as in Derge, not 【ṅar】 as N arthang or 【dar】 as Peking, which yield no sense. Bailey, Dict., s. v. 【buro】, reads 【dar】, which he says means‘little’, but there is no evidence for that and even with that meaning no sense is obtained. Bailey gives no rendering of the Tibetan with 【dar】. |||It is clear from comparison with the Tibetan version that the corresponding Khotanese 【cve hā haṃguṣṭa jsa ṇehejīdä u dārą buri va neca hame】 must mean‘when they press it down (【pīḍanān】) with the finger and it remains there for a long time in the hole (【nimno】)’. Thus, it is 【hame】 that corresponds to Tibetan 【hdug-pa】, which means‘remains’, and 【neca】 corresponds to Tibetan 【śoṅ der】‘in that hole’. |||This 【neca】‘hole’ is not isolated. As I pointed out in 【Asia Major】,XV.I, 1969, 116, 【nicu】 is to be read for Bailey's 【ni cu】 in 144r3 【KT】 1.86 (edd. 1, 2). It corresponds to Tibetan 【śoṅ】 ‘hole’. Si 25.26 (144r3-4 【KT】1.86) provides a prescription for causing a hole to be filled that has arisen after a wound has healed. The Tibetan begins: 【rma sos-pahi mal śoṅ-du gyur-pa-la ni】‘If the place where the wound has healed has become a hole’. After the prescribed treatment 【slar gaṅ-bar  hgyur-ro】‘it will become full again (【pūraṇam】)’. To this the Khotanese corresponds as follows :【khu kaṃmä jatte u nicu va hamāte ..．ṣi’ nica haṃbaḍa hame】If the wound heals and a hole should occur there ... the hole will be |||filled.’ Thus, 【nicu】and 【nica】mean ‘hole’ and correspond to Tibetan 【śoṅ】‘hole’. |||There seems to me to be no reason to look for a connection with 【ne’sta-】‘seated’ for this 【neca, nicu, nica】‘hole’. Such a connection would in any case involve a phonological difficulty since it is unlikely that the subscript hook should be absent in all three places. I would suggest therefore that the word is connected rather with 【nata-，näta-】‘deep’ .|||Note that Bailey's entry 【nica】‘again (?)’ has been abolished by the above analysis. |||[Emmerick,Ⅰ, p.63]

P 2957. 63 【KBT】34 = 【nūeśe】Ch 00266. 113 【KBT】25 <O.Kh. *【nvāśśätä】.  |||3 pl. pres. act., O.Kh.: 【nvāśśīndä】Z24. 503.|||3 sg. pf. tr. f., L.Kh.: 【nvāśā】 P 2025. 241 【KBT】 19. |||3 pl. pf. tr., L.Kh.: 【nvāśāṃde】 JS 37r4（163);【nvāśāṃdä】P 2781. 88 (20) 【KT】 3.69 <*【nvāśśätāndä】.|||Et. Iter. < *【ni-vas-】, cf. Oss. D. 【niŭŭasun】‘make a sound’.  Nouns: 【nvāsa-】Z 13. 137; 【bāsa-】P 2781. 158 (90) 【KT】3. 72 ‘trumpeting’(of elephants). B. Sogd. 【w’s- 】‘hurler’ P; O.Ind. 【vāś-】‘to roar'. See H. W. B., 【TPS】, 1945, 27. |||[Emmerick, p.62]

SVK: ‘flame’|||The fragment containing this word is from Suv: [Suv 4.12] 【nvāska­masi】‘as much as a 【nvāska’】translates Skt 【vyāma】 ‘a fathom’ (Nobel p. 49).|||Emmerick suggests that 【nvāska-】must be derived from *【ni-bāzuka-】, comparing Av. 【vībāzu-】‘fathom’. As for the development of 【-z-ka】〉【-ska­】rather than 【-ysga-】as in 【baysga-】‘thick, deep; many’ < *【bazaka-】he points out that all the known examples of this development contain 【-z-ka­­-】preceded by a short vowel , and that the development after a long vowel may have been different. This Emmerick thinks could also be the reason for the unvoiced 【-st-】 < 【-js-t-】 in 【pasūste】 instead of *【pasūysde < pasūjs-】 ­(【SGS】78). |||It should be pointed out however that the prefix 【ni-】 is an unexpected substitute for 【vi-】which contains an important semantic factor of ‘fa­thom’, the width of the outstretched arms. |||[Skjærvø,Ⅰ, p.67]|||

‘region’ (【Dict】.) |||【pa】is reduced from 【pata】, which represents the ‘older’ form as stated by Bailey. However, Bailey's assumption that 【pata】represents a feminine stem *【patā-】is arbitrary. Moreover, his proposed derivation ‘from .. . base 【pat-】 "be extended", beside 【paθ-】, Av. 【paθana-】’, which he first made known in 【BSOAS】, XXX.l, 1967, 102, is entirely without support. |||【pa(ta)】 is several times attested in the phrase 【rravyi pata】‘southern region’, which in Vajr 12a2 【KT】 3.22 renders Sanskrit 【dakṣiṇa-】...【dig-】‘southern direction’. This recalls at once Sanskrit 【dakṣiṇāpatha-】‘the southern region, Deccan’ and one is tempted to ask whether 【pata】cannot represent Sanskrit 【patha】. |||There is another word 【pata-】 in Khotanese. It is a loan from Sanskrit 【pada-】‘stanza’ via North West Prakrit (see 【Acta lranica】, 21, 1981, 186- 187). Thus 【pata-】is the regular Khotanese representation of North West Prakrit 【pada-】. Now in North West Prakrit we find such spellings as 【yada】beside 【yatha】 for Sanskrit 【yathā】 (J. Brough, 【The Gāndhārī Dharmapada】, OUP 1962, §49 p. 100) and we may assume therefore that Khotanese 【pata-】‘region’ is borrowed from a North West Prakrit *【pada】deriving from Sanskrit 【patha】. That this actually is the case is proved by Khotanese 【dakṣäṇāvatä】 Z 24.396, where the expected 【-t-】 is found for the 【-th-】 of Sanskrit【dakṣiṇāpatha】. It remains to be seen whether traces of North West Prakrit *【pada】‘region’can be found in the modern Nuristani languages. |||[Emmerick, II, p.76]
‘beside’ (【Dict】. 196b): see s.v. 【samu】. |||【pakyerma-】‘equal to; like’ 2.96. |||【pajyāre】‘they decay’ [not‘they are heated’] 1.96.|||[III, p.83]

‘flesh’|||According to Bailey【sya pa’】 in Si 3.20.15 (l7vl 【KT】1.26) means ‘flesh of goose’. In fact, 【pa’】‘flesh’ does not exist . 【pa’】is merely a scribal error for【pa’jsä】‘very’. The passage reads: 【ttekyāṃ haṃdrre-vya sya】*【pa’jsä vrriṣaṇīya】 ‘Among those (【teṣāṃ】) (water birds, flesh of) the goose (haṃso) is very virilific (vṛṣyatamas in MSS BCD).’|||*【pa’jsä vrriṣaṇīya】corresponds exactly to Sanskrit 【vṛṣyatamas】. It can be further corroborated by comparing 【pa’jsä vrriṣaṇīya】 in Si 2.9 (11v2 【KT】 1.16), which corresponds to Sanskrit 【ati-vṛṣyo】 (in MS A). |||[Emmerick,Ⅰ, p.67]

SVK: ‘defeat, overthrow’ This abstract noun occurs in 【Suv】 [6.1.62] (29v5 【KT】 5.107), where it glosses 【nyauṣca】‘defeat’. The Sanskrit differs.|||The verb is found in 【Suv】 [6.4.56], which has *【patājä[u] purrä】‘you will overcome and defeat’ corresponding to Skt. 【parājayiṣyati】. In H vii.150.13#v3 【KT】 5.82 Bailey reads only 【xx xx -ä】, but close scrutiny of the manuscript enabled me to read *【patājä[u]purrä】.|||【patāj-】 should be derived from *【apa-tāčai̯a-】‘make run back’ rather than from *【pati-tāčai̯a-】 as suggested by Bailey, as we would in that case expect 【-tt-】, cf. 【pattarrā-】‘drink’< *【pati-tṛšnā】(see above s. v. 【pattarrā-】).|||Cf. also 【byāj-】‘to dissolve’< *【u̯i-tācai̯a-】 and for 【pa-】< *【apa-】, cf. 【SGS】235.|||The past participle may be seen in LKh. 【pattīya-】, which occurs twice in P 2741 (【KT】 2.91-92), but the contexts are not clear enough to be certain: line 100 【khu durbikṣä u āphāji pattīye】‘when hunger and chaos were *overcome’ (?) and lines 122-123 【cū jsāṃṃ mistāṃ hvąṇḍā ttyāṃ hīya jsāṃ hauva ja u ñāttarāṃ hīya hīya hauva pattīya】‘if(?) the power of those great men was destroyed and the power of the lesser ones *overcome’(?).|||From other Iranian languages we may compare Man. MPers. 【abdaxt】‘to escape’and 【abdāz-】, 【abdāxt】‘to set free.’ For the variation 【pa-/ab-】 cf.,e.g., Inscr. MPers. 【pāyēs】 = Parth. 【pad(d)ēs】＝Man. MPers. 【payēs】 = Parth.【abdēs】．|||[Skjærvø, III, p.84]

SVK: 【pattarrā-】‘drink’[not‘food’ as 【Dict】. 204b]|||According to Skjærvø,‘[t]he exact meaning of 【pattarrā-】 has not yet|||been definitively established’ (【Suv】 3.121), though he consistently translates the 【Suv】 occurrences of the word by‘drink, beverage’. SVK: 【patisu】‘in autumn’ 1.68|||On the meaning and attestations of this word see Skjærvø, 【BSOAS】,XLIV.3 1981, 463-465. The form of the word is still problematic. According to D. Hitch, 【IIJ】，33.3, 1990, 197, the form cannot be explained from a stem *【pataśa-】 with the ending【-u】 by synchronic rules. Another possibility would then be to derive it from an Old Iranian adverbial form *【《o》zi̯am】meaning‘verging upon winter.’Thus, the 【-u】 would not be an ending,|||but part of the original stem.|||[Skjærvø,III, p.85]

SVK: Bailey quotes P 2786.243—244 【KT】 2.101 ca vä pabauna yai ttu jairmāṃ sturāṃ vą pīhą hūḍāṃda and translates ‘what for them (ca-ṃ va?—Bailey) was the charge, they gave that as price of the excellent large cattle’, giving an etymology for 【pabauna】. However, such a word does not exist. It is simply the result of a misreading for 【pamauḍa】, the past participle of 【patämar-】 ‘to report’ (【SGS】 67). The above passage should be read 【ca vä pamauḍa yai ttu jairmāṃ stūrau vą pīhą hūḍāṃda】 and translated ‘As the price of the excellent draft horses, they gave what had been reported’. [kumamoto, II, p.79]

DKS: see 【patämar-】; noun, Ⅲ 70.125 【paṃmare bve】 ‘I know the report of her’; Ⅲ 70.109 【paṃmarai bvīrau aśka】 ‘you perhaps know the report of her’; Ⅲ 70.111【 paṃmara bvāta】 ‘you may know the report’.
‘reported’, Ⅲ 83-20; Ⅲ 110-12 pamauḍa, 11 87-52 pamāṃḍa, see patämar-.

SGS: ‘to bring out; present’ ppp. 【puḍa-】[p.72]

DKS: aśä ‘horse with cart’, Ⅱ 111’16, if from *pa(ti)- raθa- ‘associated with cart’, see raha- ‘wagon, chariot’. Translation AM, n.s., Ⅱ, 1964, 2 with note 12.
‘sold’, v 222.22.3, see SDTV 83 (plate 61), from older 【parāta-】, in a fragment /// 【va parā, mūri】 300.
‘you are to deign to’, 11 10.163 【parä spāṣṭai】 ‘deign to look’, 2 sing, -ā to base 【par-,pary-】 to ‘order’; see SDTV 33.
late tor 【parau】 ‘ order ’, 1140.31 【khu ttu rrvī parā hagrātta yainu】 ‘if I can uphold that royal command’. See 【parau】.
‘injure’, Ⅲ 6, 13^ ma thursa ma nvamthi ma vanāsa, ma parājsañä ‘ do not harm, do not change, do not shake, do not injure’, see parājsan-.
‘injure, destroy’, Ⅲ 6, 13r4 【ma parājsañä】 ‘do not injure’; = Ⅲ 10, 19v5 【ma par<a>jsañä】. From 【*parā- j̆an-】, see 【jsan-: jsata-】 ‘strike’.
‘to sell’, present, K 17-170 vara maparātha ‘there sell me’ (Manoharā), =K 25-109 vara ma parātha, = K 33*58 vira ma parāthä', K 41-60 nva pīhi: pirāthyarä
‘guide to the road’, K 147.29, for 【padā-rāysau】, see s.v. 【pande】.

SVK: This word was shown by Emmerick (śgs 78) to be locative plural of 【parräta-】 ‘elapsed, past’ from 【pars-】 ‘to escape, elapse (of time)’ (also Emmerick, 【JRAS】, 1969, 65). For the form cf. e. g. 【paljsovo'】 ‘in the enclosures’ from 【paljsätā-】 (Z 3.58). [Skjærvø, I, p.68]

SVK:
‘surrounded’ ||| Bailey fails to distinguish between the two words 【paljsata-】 ‘surroun­ded*, past participle of 【paljsan-】, and 【paljsätā-】 ‘an enclosure’. This distinction is clearly demonstrated by the passages quoted by Bailey. ||| It is possible to derive 【paljsätā-】 from 【paljsata-】 assuming weakening of the interior 【a】 to 【ä】 as in Old Khotanese 【bätavā-】, 【bätävā-】 ‘lightning’ (both in Z) and 【hvatana-】, 【hvatäna-】 ‘Khotanese’ (Z and Suv). Nevertheless, it is tempting to speculate whether 【paljsätā】 may not be from *【paričitā-】, cf. Manichaean Middle Persian 【przyd】 ‘shut in’, 【prcyn】 and 【przyn】 ‘fence, wall’. Cf. also Skt 【parici-】 ‘to surround or enclose with (instr.)’ (Monier- Williams) beside 【parikhan-】 ‘to dig round’ (Monier-Williams). For the form cf. 【jäta- ‹ *j̆ita- (SGS 35)】 and 【däta ‹ dīta】- (【SGS】 47). [Skjærvø, I, p.68] ||| My suggestion in 【Studies】 1, 68 that 【palsjätā-】 ‘enclosure’ may derive from *【paričitā-】 was ill-advised. Comparison with e.g. 【jin-】 ‘to destroy’ ‹ *【j̆inā-ti】 shows that Old Iranian 【č】 and 【j̆】 did not depalatalize before 【i.】 See S. Konow, 【Saka Studies】, Oslo 1932, 25 and N. Sims-Williams,【 BSOAS】, XLVI.2, 1983, 359. ||| The different vowel qualities and the different LKh. forms are then perhaps best explained by assuming different accentuation, the effects of which are here similar to those seen in 【hämäte】 ‘he is, becomes’ › LKh. 【häme (hime, etc.)】, but 【hämätä】 ‘he was, became’ › LKh. (【*hämäye ›) himye】. The past participle 【paljsata-】 and the 3 singular 【hämäte】 may have been accented on the first syllable, which would account for the reduction of their final syllables, whereas 【paljsatā-】 and the past participle 【hämäta-】 may have had a different accent, which can then only have been on the final syllable: 【paljsatā́-】 › 【paljsätā-】 › *【pa’jsäyā-】 › 【pa’jsyā-】, and 【hämätá-】 › *【hämäya-】 › 【himya-】. For the development of 【-at-́ 】› 【-ät-́】, cf. OKh. 【thatau】 ‘quick’ › 【thätau】 › LKh. 【thyau】, see above s.v. 【thatau】 ‘at once, swiftly’. ||| It must be pointed out, however, that Khotanese accentuation is only little known yet, and the above explanations are meant as suggestions only.
[Skjærvø, II, p.80]

Under【pa’sa】‘messenger’, P 2786.63-64 【KT】2.95 【khu vą̄ īṣṭą pasa kāṣṭa khu ttyai hyą vā pā phara na ra hīśta】 is translated ‘When he returned, the messenger considered how no longer does a report of his come’. SVK: an unknown commodity [not ‘of messengers’ as 【Dict】. 225a]||| The word 【pa’sīñä】 is found on a wooden stick in the I.O.L. W[ood] 3 in an unintelligible context: (al) 【khattīnai svirrnadattä pu’sū pa’sīñä 7 cha ura -ūṃ (2) x ñau saṃ kūsa】 ‘I Khattīnai ask after Svirmadatta (?). 【pa’sīñä 7 《*》chās】and ...【a kūsa (?)】.’ It occurs also in a long letter from Mazar Tagh (M.T. a. 1.0033 #4-5 【KT】2.71 【SDTV】1.73): 【pasām āstaṃna stūra kai ’tta khvaṃ tta na panāśari ci tta aśnesalą̄ña pa’sīña drą̄ma ṣṭāri yāṃ kum y- hauryari khu na hvā’re】 ‘Look after the sheep and the other domestic animals so that none are lost for me. Whatever *such 【pa’sīñas】 there are from Aśnesala (?), give them to Yāṃ Kuṃ Y-(?) so that they do not *dry up.|||These passages seem to rule out Emmerick’s suggestion in 【SDTV】3.153 that the 【pa’sīña-】 might be ‘water holes for sheep.’ Hides, of course, might dry up and become useless, but other possibilities no doubt exist.|||[Skjærvø,III, p.89]

SVK: This unique word has been invented on the strength of a single Late Khotanese passage only, P 2026.56—57 【KT】 3.50. In fact, 【pā】 is a Late Khotanese form of 【pātcu】‘next, then’. It often occurs in enclitic position following a pronoun but may be postponed if other particles occur as here.|||The passage has been misunderstood by Bailey. For the idea behind it, compare Z 4.93-6 and 9.14—16.|||【ṣa’bvauma cu paysaida ṣa’ rā jsāna bvāma pā rusta】|||【varā drą̄ma na bīde sa khu dai āca pasūśte 43】|||‘This bodhi, when one recognises (by it the ultimate reality, paramārtha)- this bodhi is indeed then lost. No such (thing) is found there just as a flame of fire burns.’|||As the passages in Z show, what is meant is that bodhi does not exist objectively, it is just a parikalpa, a notion, which disappears when by it the ultimate reality is recognised. It is like the lye which when it has cleaned the garment itself dissolves or the fire which burns up the fire grate.|||For 【āca】‘flame’, not‘water’as Bailey, see s. v. 【āca】‘in water’. |||[Emmerick, I, 70-71]

pā(’)ste‘done’|||Suv 3.27 (P 64r4 【KT】 1.244) 【cu... kleśī'nyau naṣṭāvyau jsa, biśū̜ñi baśde'pā'ste 】‘whatever various sins I have committed through the burnings of the kleśas', Skt. (Nobel p. 27) 【vicitraiḥ kleśa-saṃtāpair yat tu pāpaṃ kṛtaṃ mayā】. The form can be a 1 singular perfect transitive, with LKh. 【-te】 < OKh. 【-taima】 (so Bailey, Dict.) or past participle nominative accusative plural feminine agreeing with 【baśde】’. Note the subscript hookhere and in 【pa'tte】.|||[Skjærvø, II, p.84-85]

SVK: ‘clyster-pipe’ (【Dict.】)|||The meaning of Khotanese 【pīlīrua-】‘clyster-pipe’ is made clear by Si 18.55 (12lr3--4 【KT】 1.48): 【varī vī tvā khu̜ṇā ne haṃbrą̄ñą̄ñä u pīlīrū vī hā viśtą̄ñä u bve̜’śda’ paśą̄ñä khu vā buḍa ysauttä】‘The hole must not be made to heal at once, and it must be placed in a clyster-pipe, and (the urine) must be released into it for a long time so that more flows into it.’|||[Emmerick，II, p.90-91]

SVK: Bailey’s translation of 【braṣṭäñe jsa aysu】 T asked’ (last two lines of p. 245) can only have been intended to tease students of Khotanese. The passage from Suv [Suv 16.24] runs as follows:[...] 【*vījye】 (Leumann for 【vījyo】) 【braṣṭäñe jsa aysu biśśu ve ...】, Skt 【yena dhātu-kauśalyena paripṛṣtenāhaṃ sarvatra ... upasaṃkramiṣyāmi】 ‘with the skill in the elements (which I) asked about, I shall go everywhere’ (Nobel p. 176). Thus 【braṣṭäñe jsa】 is an adjectival past participle qualifying the preceding word and 【aysu】 goes with what follows, 【braṣṭāñe jsa aysu】 is therefore not an inverted passive (agential) construction expressing past tense as Bailey’s translation might lead one to think. 【*vījye braṣṭāñe jsa】 means ‘with the asked-about science’. [Skjsærvø, I, p.75]

DKS: ‘at once, swiftly’ dyadic with 【thyau】 ‘at once’ and 【raysga vī】 ‘swiftly’
SVK:
No bilingual evidence has yet been found to settle the precise meaning of 【puṣṣo】. The meaning given in the Diet, by Bailey marks a return to the meaning given by S. Konow in Saka Studies, Oslo 1932, 173: ‘【puṣṣo】, at once, immediately, M 109 etc., 【-ṣṣa】, 【-ṣa】 N 76【42】, 158【8】, V’.
Subsequently Konow appears to have changed his mind concerning the meaning of 【puṣṣo】 since in his 【Khotansakische Grammatik】, Leipzig 1941, 118 he has: 【‘puṣṣo】 wieder, gänzlich’ and in his 【Primer of Khotanese Saka】, Oslo 1949, 113, we find: 【‘puṣṣo】, altogether, wholly, again’. [Emmerick, II, p.91]
see above on 【pāsta】 ‘committed, done’, etc. [II, p.94]

SVK: Bailey explains this hapax as ‘from 【frīna-】 (or 【frīvana-】) with dialectal or archaic 【fr-】 kept’. In fact all three words beginning with 【phrr-】 that are listed in the 【Dict.】, are loanwords from Tibetan. For 【phrrūmä】 ‘thickened milk’ from Tibetan 【phrum】 see below s. v. 【phrramaina】 was correctly identified by Bailey as representing Tibetan 【phra-men】 although he wishes to regard 【phra-men】 as borrowed from Iranian. The Tibetan 【phra-men】 cannot be from Khotanese because no Khotanese word of Iranian origin has 【phrr-】. Old Iranian 【*fr-】 develops regularly to Khotanese 【br-】 as in 【bria-】 ‘beloved’, cf. Avestan 【friia-】, Old Indian 【priyá-】.||| According to Bailey 【phrrīnä】 ‘parallels 【nāśa】 “tenderness”’, but there is no guarantee that 【nāśa】 is parallel with 【phrrīnä】 in the sense of being synonymous with it: the lovers can send more than one thing to one another. In any case the reading of the first akṣara of 【nāśa】 does not seem to me to be established beyond doubt.||| 【phrrīnä】 is clearly a loanword from Tibetan 【(h)phrin】 ‘message’. 【śūjäñāṣṭä phrrīnä paśīdä】 in P 2895.28 KT 3.41 means ‘they send messages to one another’, not as Bailey renders ‘they give out mutual love’. 【-āṣṭä】 is the directional suffix ‘towards’ and paś- means ‘to send’, 【paś-】 is used with 【haḍa】 ‘messengers’ in P 2790.112 KT 2.114 【haḍa paśarä】 ‘send messengers’.||| See 【Die Sprache】, 29, 1983.|||  [Emmerick, Ⅰ, p.81]

SVK: In 【Sgh】 83r6 【KT】 5.341 Bailey reads 【bando】 for Konow’s 【ban[d]o】 and cites it in 【Dict.】 269a as his first example for 【baṃda-】 ‘binding’. But in fact, inspection of the manuscript in the India Office Library, London, revealed no trace of a subscript 【-d-】 in this word. Since Khotanese has a word 【banaa-】 ‘prisoner’, which can easily be derived from 【bana-】 ‘prison’ there does not seem to be any reason for emending the manuscript reading, and we should read the 【Sgh】 passage: 【bano kaṣṭumä rruīya】 ‘I fell into/was bound in the royal prison’. See also above on 【jjaṣṭumä】 ‘I came’.|||[Skjsærvø, Ⅲ, p.105]

SVK: The likelihood that 【bitte】 ‘cuts off’ should be found in Si 21.14 (130r5 【KT】 1.62) only is not very great. From Bailey’s rendering of 【khvai bitte】 as ‘so that it cuts it off’, it is not apparent that 【bitte】 has to mean in fact not just ‘cuts off’ but ‘terminates diarrhoea’.......Despite the evidence that encourages us to look for ‘purges’ in 【bitte】, it is possible that the Khotanese version does not correspond exactly either to the Sanskrit or to the Tibetan. The most likely explana_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x001f_tion of 【bitte】 now seems to me to be that it is a variant spelling of 【baitte】 ‘is bound’......It is easier to understand ‘it is bound’ as meaning ‘the downward motion is bound’ than to understand ‘it cuts off’ as meaning ‘it cuts off the downward motion’. Firstly, ‘the downward motion is bound’ is attested in Khotanese 【nāstä-ga baitte】. Secondly, 【baitte】 by itself recalls Sanskrit 【vibandha-】 and 【baddha-】 used in this way. On the other hand, 【bitte】 ‘it cuts off’ is not only not attested in an expression of the required meaning, but it does not have the meaning ‘cuts off’ anywhere else either.[Emmerick,I, p.87 ]

SVK:
【biśi】 at ‘Sid. 131rl’ (= Si 21.16) and 【beśi】 at ‘Sid. 20v5’ (= Si 3.26.12) are said by Bailey to correspond to ‘BS 【mastu】’, which, if true, would be 
disturbing because at the three places where Sanskrit 【mastu】 occurs in parts of the Sanskrit text of which the Khotanese version is extant 【mastu】 is rendered, as expected, as 【ñyetutca】 ‘the watery part of thick sour milk’. |||In fact, in both Si 3.26.12 and 21.16 【biśī】, 【beśī】 corresponds to Sanskrit takra ‘buttermilk’ (= Tibetan 【dar-ba】).|||In Si 1.56.18 (9v2, not 9r2 as 【Dict.】, KT 1.14) 【biśi】 corresponds to Sanskrit 【udaśvit】 ‘buttermilk’ (= Tibetan 【dar-ba】). The difference between takra and 【udaśvit】 lies in the relative proportion of water (see Meulenbeld pp. 465—7). [Emmerick, I, p.89]

This unique word has been invented for one passage only, Mañj 353【KBT】151. In fact the passage can be satisfactorily interpreted with the ordinary meaning of 【bīsa】 as ‘slave’. See on 【pvah-】 ‘strike’ above.[Emmerick,I,p.90]

B ppp. 【bihaṃtta-】|||3 sg. pres, mid., O.Kh.: 【bihante】 Z 5. 26 (? 【bihatte】 3 sg. pf. tr. m.).|||3 pl. pres, act., L.Kh.: 【byahanīda】 P 2956. 20 【KT】 3. 37 = id. Ch 00266. 24 【KT】3. 35 = 【byihänīdä】 P 2025. 36-37 【KT】 3. 47.|||2 sg. pf. tr. m., O.Kh.: 【bihaṃttai】 【SS】 27r1 【KT】 5. 333 tr. 【hj́um-pa mj́ad-pa.】|||3 sg. pf. tr. m., O.Kh.: 【bihaṃtte】 【SS】 20V5 【KT】 5. 330; 【bihaṃtte】 E 6. 46 (Leumann 【bihąnte】).|||Et. ‹ 【*vi-xand-】, v. 【khan-】 p. 25.|||[p.99]

SVK: All the examples cited by Bailey s. v. 【bihīta-】 are translated by him as ‘exceeding(ly)’ or ‘very’, except for the first example, that from JS 18v2 (79), where he renders 【bihīvī】 ‘you mounted up’, 【bihīta-】, 【bihīya-】 ‘exceeding(ly)’ is past participle from 【byihaṃj-】 ‘to increase’ (see s. v. 【byihaṃj-】 below), 【bihīvī】 is evidently to be separated from 【bihīta-】 ‘exceeding(ly)’ as the divergent meaning shows. In my article on ‘Khotanese 【bihīya】 again’ in 【BSOAS】, XLIV.3, 1981, 450, I suggested that 【bihīva-】 in JS 18v2 (79) 【bihīvī】 is past participle from 【*bihaj- ‹ *abi-xač-aya-】 or 【*abi-xaǰ-aya-】 ‘to raise’. The treatment of *【-x-】 postulated here would be the same as seen in 【bīhan-】 ‘to smile’ from 【*vi-xand-】 beside the simplex 【khan-】 ‘to laugh’. The base 【*xač-】 or 【*xaǰ-】 ‘to rise’ is found in 【uskhajs-】 ‘to rise’.|||[Emmerick,I,p.90]

That 【bihīys-】 means ‘to increase’ or ‘to expand’ (intransitive) and not ‘to decrease’, as had previously been thought, was demonstrated in my article in 【JRAS】, 1967, 22—25. Bailey now adds the meaning ‘mount’ to 【bihīys-】 on the strength of 【bihīṣṭa】, which occurs once only in the obscure Book of Vimalakīrti 340—341【 KBT】 110.|||[Emmerick,I,p.90-91]

【bują̄ñ-】 means ‘to revitalise’, not to ‘use as food’. It is causative to the verb listed in Dict, as 【‘būjv-】 “revive” ’ and not as stated here ‘causative to 【būj-】 base 【baug-】 “use as food (?)” ’.|||[Emmerick,II,p.113]

That 【būña】 is unlikely to be loc. sing, from ‘Iranian 【būma-】’ is shown by Bailey’s second example: 【acala ṣā haṣṭama būña】 (Vim 226 【KBT】104),which he renders ‘Acalā, this is the eighth bhūmi-stage’. With 【ṣā】 we expect the nominative.|||Bailey wishes to find 【būma-】 in 【būña】 because Vim 225 has 【kṣema būma】 ‘sixth bhūmi-stage’, but there we have the name of the 【bhūmi】 followed by 【nāma: kṣema būma abvaimvakha nāma】 ‘the sixth 【bhūmi】 called Abhimukhī’. 【būña】 is in fact a Late Khotanese spelling for 【bvāña】 ‘to be known’ like 【hūñ-】 beside 【hvāñ-】 ‘to speak’ (on which see Dict. s.v. 【hvan-】; cf. 【SGS】 156 and 【Studies I】 pp. 16, 130). Thus, Vim 226 【KBT】 104 【acala ṣā haṣṭama būña】 means ‘Acalā, that is to be known as the eighth (【bhūmi】)’. Bailey’s first example, however, does not have 【duragama haudama būña】 as in Dict, and both editions of 【KBT】 but 【duragama haudama būma】 (Vim 226 【KBT】 104)‘Dūraṃgamā (is) the seventh 【bhūmi】’. The reading is quite clear. Bailey’s reading 【būña】 presumably goes back to an old typing error.|||[Emmerick,II,p.113-114]

According to Bailey not only 【buḍara】 means ‘more’ but also 【buḍatta】. However, contextual analysis clearly shows that 【buḍatta】 means ‘(very) much’. Bailey renders 【buḍatta neśą̄ñä】 in Si 23.17 (137r5 【KT】1.74) as ‘more is to be poured’. In fact, after the ghee has been beaten a hundred times until it becomes white, 【vara hā mahābuṃjä hīya cuṇya buḍatta neśą̄ñä】 ‘into it must be put very much （【-utkaṭam】） powder of liquorice 【(yaṣṭī-madhu-)】'. The Tibetan【 śas cher】 ‘in large quantity’ agrees with both Sanskrit 【utkaṭa】 and Khotanese 【buḍatta】 ‘(very) much’.|||[Emmerick,I,p.91-93]

SGS: ‘to destroy’ V e tr. A|||1pl. pres., L.Kh.: 【būrvāṃ】 P 2781. 138 (70) 【KT】 3. 71.|||3sg. pres., L.Kh.: 【burrvai】 P 4099. 411 【KBT】 134 (cf.【 pajsīnde】 Z 5. 86) ‹ 【*burūväte】.|||Et. ‹ 【*vi-raup-】 cf. NP【 rūb-, ruftan 】H. W. B., 【BSOAS】, x. 3, 1941, 586. Parth. 【pdrb-】 ‘mettre en déroute’ ‹ 【*pati-raup-】 (Ghilain, p. 65); B. Sogd. 【rwp-】 ‘cueillir’ 【VJ】|||[p.101]
‘to split, tear’|||[p.103]

DKS: second component in uncertain miscellany, II 51.97 【ttugarā-baira】and 【kava-baira】(if the syllables are correctly grouped) where 【ttugarā-】 might mean ‘tubers’ and 【kava-】 ‘fish’.

SVK: 【biśī】 at ‘Sid. 131rl’ (= Si 21.16) and 【beśī】 at ‘Sid. 20v5’ (= Si 3.26.12) are said by Bailey to correspond to ‘BS 【mastu’】, which, if true, would be disturbing because at the three places where Sanskrit 【mastu】 occurs in parts of the Sanskrit text of which the Khotanese version is extant 【mastu】 is rendered, as expected, as 【ñyetutca】 ‘the watery part of thick sour milk’.|||In fact,in both Si 3.26.12 and 21.16 【biśī,beśī】corresponds to Sanskrit 【takra】‘buttermilk’.|||[Emmerick; I, p.89]

【borṣai】 occurs only in Si 25.33 (144v5 【KT】 1.86). Bailey renders 【hatcastä u borṣai-vī hvīḍa】as ‘food for fracture and protrusion’. He explains 【borṣai-vī】 as ‘having protruding parts’, 【hatcastä】 is literally ‘broken’ and is so explained by Bailey s. v. 【hatcañ-】 ‘to break’. It is no doubt to be understood as meaning ‘broken (bone)’ since this concept is in the context. In fact, Si 25.32 has 【bhinnāsthi-】 ‘broken bone’, which is rendered in the Khotanese version by 【āstai hatcyą̄ve】. It is misleading to quote here, as Bailey does, the Sanskrit of Si 25.32 beside the Khotan­ese and Tibetan of Si 25.33, but it is nevertheless likely that the broken bone and dislocated joint of Si 25.32 are intended also in Si 25.33. That being so, the ‘protrusion’ expressed by Tibetan 【bur-ba】 is likely to be protrusion resulting from dislocation.|||[Emmerick; I, p.95]

DKS: see【byaha, biha; byahaṃj-, byihaṃj-; byahan-, bihan-】.
‘means of crossing (river)’,possibly inflated skin, in the mountain

SVK: 【byarivā】 is to be read 【bvari vā】. The akṣara 【bva】 is found at the end of the line and only half of it remains. The subscript 【-v-】 has a sharp edge to the left but sharp-edged varieties of subscript 【-v-】 are attested elsewhere also in cursive script. The 【bva】 does not in any case resemble【 by】 in【 byihi’】 in line 40. The passage in question is:【 cū bvari vā ysathvā jsāna ttaradara bīśā’ prraeina * aysmūna yuḍi ttyi karma biśa vasasīdū u jāra】 (Ch 0048.40—41【 KBT】 73) ‘However much he may have done in (his) births on account of (his) body (and) tongue (or) due to (his) mind, all his karmas will become pure and disappear.’ Correct accordingly Bailey’s rendering in 【Buddhist studies in honour of I. B. Horner】, ed. L. Cousins et al., Dordrecht 1974, p. 17. 【cū bvari vā】 is a LKh. continuation of OKh. 【cu buro vātcu】 (Z 12.7).|||[Emmerick; II, p.114]
【pajyāre u byavāre】 in Si 26.84 (156rl 【KT】 1.102) is here rendered ‘they are heated and morbid’ whereas in 【Dict】. s. v. 【pajs-】 Bailey renders ‘they are heated and burn’.|||[Emmerick; I, p.96]
byāña- ‘to be increased’[not ‘to be produced,made,divided’]1.98.|||[Emmerick; III, p.119]

In the 【Dict】, this item occurs out of alphabetical order following 【byāñä】 ‘to be produced, made, divided’ q. v. The word occurs only in Avdh 20v3—4 【KT】3.11: 【vaña tvā haṭhṭha u ttä mista prraṇihāna byāñą huṣṣāñu bihīśų】, ‘now make increase, make grow, expand this truth and these great vows’, 【byāñą, huṣṣāñu, and bihīśų】, are all causatives meaning ‘make increase’, 【byāñą】is 2 sg. imperative from 【by-āñ-】, which is formed by the addition of the secondary causative suffix 【-āñ-】 (on which see 【SGS】185) to the present stem 【by-】 ‘to increase’ (on which see 【byāñä】 below). The formation is paralleled by the accompanying word 【huṣṣāñ-】 ‘to make grow’, causative from 【huṣṣ-】 ‘to grow’. Bailey’s etymology ‘from *【vitānaya- 】“to extend”’ resulted from his failure to recognise 【by-】 ‘to increase’.|||[Emmerick; I, p.98]

SVK: ‘beloved’|||In the Suv passage quoted by Bailey (SuvK. 67v2 【KT】 5.118), for Bailey's 【manävä】 we must read 【ttagatä】. The word is rubbed but legible.The passage is as follows: [Suv 13.2] ṣä härä arthä ttagatä brī x《1》 vä，Skt 【tad vastu priyaṃ manäpaṃ】(Nobel p. 146). We see that Skt 【vastu】has been rendered triadically in the Khotanese, and that for Skt 【priyaṃ】we have the expected 【brī】‘dear’. The Khotanese word corresponding to Skt 【manäpaṃ】apparently contains only two syllables, but even close scrutiny of the photograph of the manuscript has not revealed the correct reading. Possibly one should read【ma(nā)vä】, i. e. with omitted 【nā-akṣara】, but that is conjectural. At any rate the reading 【brītañä】 is wholly unwarranted.|||[Skjærvø,I, p.100]

【brīyanda】 occurs first in V. S. Vorob’ev-Desjatovskij and M. I.Vorob’eva-Desjatovskaja, 【Skazanie o Bhadre (novye listy sakskoj rukopisi ‘E’)】, Moscow 1965, p. 37. There it was explained (p. 84) as nom. singular fem. of a present participle. In 【BSOAS】, XXX.l, 1967, 85 I pointed out that two words are involved: 【brī】 and 【yanda】. 【brī】 is the regular form for
the accusative singular masculine of 【bria-】. 【yanda】 is 3 singular injunctive,here used, as commonly, in a hypothetical relative clause.|||【ṣa ju māta näśtä kye pūru śśau-ysātu tterä brī yanda|||crrāmu tvī balysa hamaṅgu biśśä sarvasatva uysnora】 (Z 2.180)|||‘The mother does not exist who feels (lit. makes) her only-born son as beloved as are all beings equally to you, Buddha.’|||With this can be compared Z 11.6:【avachauda mulysdä hamaṃgga kyai ne brī yande aysmūna|||hamaṃggai haṃ vite mulysdä kho rro ttu väte cī brī yande】|||‘Compassion is unhindered, equal. Compassion is always equal for one who does not have love in his mind for one as also towards him when he does have love for one.’|||Bailey has here without justification resuscitated 【brīyanda】 apparently for Z 2.180 only. He renders 【ṣa ju māta näśta kye pūru śśau-ysātu tterä brīyanda】 as ‘this mother is not who holds the only-born son so dear’. His ‘holds’ is apparently represented by a‘suffix 【-vant-】, with 【-a < -u’】 added to 【brīyā】‘love’. Everywhere else the suffix takes the form 【-aunda】 e.g. 【puñaunda-】 ‘meritorious’, 【virśonda-】 ‘heroic’, 【bu' jsauda-】‘virtuous’ (see Dresden, JS, p. 419). The suffix of 【brīyanda】 must also govern the accusative 【pūru】 !|||[Emmerick,I, p.100-101]

(intr.), O.Kh.: 【braudaimä】 H 142 NS 48 etc. r1 【KT】5. 71.|||Et. < *【brāmaya-】 iter. < *【bram-】, cf. Parth. 【brm-】 ‘pleurer’ (Ghilain,p. 56), v. H. W. B., 【BSOS】, ix. 1, 1937, 73.|||[p.107]

In fact the forms belong to 【bud-】‘to know’and 【buvan-】‘to destroy’.|||Avdh 20v5 【KT】 3.11 【crrāmä maṃ āśśayä bvā】‘how you may know my intent (to be)’. Here 【bvā】 is 2 sg. subjunctive middle of 【bud-】, cf.【SGS】 204.|||[Skjærvø,I, p.102-103]

SVK: This unique word owes its existence to the misreading of an akṣara, the wrong division of syllables, and the misinterpretation of the passage in which it occurs. ||| According to Bailey 【ṣā’ mvarye tta hasta bvāña】 (Mañj 291 【KBT】 127) means ‘this course of action is so to be known as the best’. However, as pointed out to me by Almuth Degener, the passage must be read 【ṣā’ mvadetta hasta bvāña】 and rendered ‘That is to be known as excellent joy’. 【mvadetta】 is Buddhist Sanskrit 【muditā】 ‘joy’, one of the four infinitudes (【apramāṇa】).[Emmerick, Ⅱ, p.118]

SVK: The stem is 【ysarratara-】 (with Bailey, 【Dict】. 347 s.v. 【ysarrarä】), not 【ysarrataraa-】 (so Degener, 【Suffixe】 21), as shown by the final short 【-e】 in 【Z】 23《37》 【ysarrätare】 nom.-acc. pl. (cf. 【MacKenzie Fs.】, 1991, 67-73) at the end of a pāda consisting of five morae plus the cadence  (【pīrāka ysarrätare daśta】). The stem is confirmed by LKh. StH 40 【KT】 2.74 【ysarrarä】 nom. sg. with final 【-ä】, not 【-e】 or 【-ai】, which one would expect in the case of an 【aa-】 stem (see 【SGS】 297). According to Degener, 【Suffixe】 20, the compound element 【-gara-】 is unknown in Old Khotanese, but this is contradicted by both 【ysarra-tara-】 and Z 2《91》 【śśäraṃgäri】 nom. sg. to 【śśäraṃ-gara-】 ‘skilful’.  [Maggi, Ⅲ, p.129]

SVK:
Probably a form of 【ysāra-】 ‘a thousand’. ||| 
Bailey quotes this word from P2787.30—32 【KT】 2.102: 【ysą̄ryai brrūnyai naramāṇä-kāyījyā bvaiyyau jsa kūla sa-ysairvą̄ cą̄vadīvą̄ mahā- karaṇijyā sa-ysairyą̄ bvaiyą̄ jsa】 ‘with a thousand *splendid rays (issuing) from the ‘transformation body’ (【nirmāṇa-kāya】), in a billion (【koṭi】) hundred thousand four-continents (【cāturdvīpikā, Z cātädīviā-】) with a hundred thousand rays of great compassion’. ||| [Emmerick, Ⅱ, p.119]

【ysālva】 occurs frequently in the medical texts, but Bailey quotes only ‘Sid. 121r1 【ysālva】, BS 【niśā】 (“turmeric”), Tib. 【skyer-pa】 “shrub with yellow flowers” ’ [Emmerick, Ⅰ, p.106]  ||| see s.v.【cuvaṃ】and 【studies I】 p.106 . [Emmerick, Ⅱ, p.121]

An unpublished Leningrad folio of Sgh has: 【ko muhu ysīttaru gyastu [balysu vajsä'] tāmane】 (Herzenberg IX + XIVr1) ‘Would that we may soon see the Lord Buddha’ to render Skt. 【drakṣyāma śīghraṃ saṃbud-dham】 (verse 194 in O. von Hinüber’s edition). Thus, the adverb ysīttaru means ‘soon’ and corresponds to Skt. 【śīghram】. [Emmerick, Ⅱ, p.121]

SVK: To sum up: the 【Sudh】 passage under consideration is to be reconstruct_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x001F_ed as 【sye mura jīvajīvā *karavīra cāṣe】’ ‘(there were) geese, pheasants, Indian cuckoos (and) jays’; A 【karivīnā】 ‘all around’ is a 【lectio facilior】 for 【*karavīra】 ‘Indian cuckoo’; and P 【ravīnā】 and C 【ra】 are further mistakes in the tradition. In particular, a word ravīnā does not exist for it is merely a corrupt reading.[Maggi, III,132]

SVK: ‘made’ （【Dict. 】374a)|||In 【BSOAS】, XLIV.3, 1981, 447-448 and 【Studies】 2.126-127 Emmerick suggests that 【vadanda-】 ‘made’ may have been created by reanalysis of the negative form 【a-vadanda-】 ‘not made’, which really derives from privative 【a-】 + 【padanda-】 ‘made’ with the usual development of intervocalic 【-p-】to 【-v-】. While this explanation is certainly possible, it is worth pointing out that the older derivation of 【vadanda-】 from 【*awa-dam-】 (thus 【Dict.】) receives support from the recently discovered Christian Sogdian compound 【zprt-’wd’my】 ‘making pure’ (translating Syriac 【mḥllnyt】 ‘cleanser’ or 【mqdšnyt】 ‘sanctifier’); see 【BSOAS】, LVIII.1, 1955, 59.[Sims-Williams]|||[Sims-Williams,III, p.135]

SVK: In BSOAS, XLVIII. 1, 1985, 60—73, I have shown that these two words are one and the same and signify ‘door, (palace) gate’, possibly ‘(royal) court’, but not ‘courtyard’.|||Khot. 【vara-】 is obviously from Old Iranian 【*dwar-】 (with later thematicization) and exhibits the same development of 【*dw › v】 that we find in Tumshuqese 【vitana】 ‘a second time’ (Karmavācanā 2 and 8)《1》 from 【*dwita~】. The corresponding Khot. form 【śäta-】 (i.e. 【/źeda-/】) ‘second’ has a diverging development of 【*dw-】: here it coalesces with Old Iranian 【*dźw-】from Indo-European 【*ĝhw-】, see Emmerick in: 【Monumentum Georg Morgenstierne】, I, 199 ( = 【Acta iranica】, 21, Leiden 1981).|||The use of the word for ‘door’ to signify ‘gate, palace gate’ is found in Old Persian (DB. 2. 75, 89 f.), Middle Persian (【dar】, heterogram 【BBA】) and Parthian (【bar】, heterogram 【TROA】), and in Sogdian (Vessantara Jātaka 80).|||For other Khot. words containing old 【*dw- 】(or 【*θw-】), see on 【vāj-】 ‘hold’, 【vāñ-】 ‘to toss’ and 【uysvāñätä】 ‘tosses up’, 【vāna-】 ‘dwelling place’|||[Skjærvø,II, p.125]

In BSOAS, XLVIII. 1, 1985, 60—73, I have shown that these two words are one and the same and signify ‘door, (palace) gate’, possibly ‘(royal) court’, but not ‘courtyard’.|||Khot. 【vara-】 is obviously from Old Iranian 【*dwar-】 (with later thematicization) and exhibits the same development of 【*dw › v】 that we find in Tumshuqese 【vitana】 ‘a second time’ (Karmavācanā 2 and 8)《1》 from 【*dwita~】. The corresponding Khot. form 【śäta-】 (i.e. 【/źeda-/】) ‘second’ has a diverging development of 【*dw-】: here it coalesces with Old Iranian 【*dźw-】from Indo-European 【*ĝhw-】, see Emmerick in: 【Monumentum Georg Morgenstierne】, I, 199 ( = 【Acta iranica】, 21, Leiden 1981).|||The use of the word for ‘door’ to signify ‘gate, palace gate’ is found in Old Persian (DB. 2. 75, 89 f.), Middle Persian (【dar】, heterogram 【BBA】) and Parthian (【bar】, heterogram 【TROA】), and in Sogdian (Vessantara Jātaka 80).|||For other Khot. words containing old 【*dw- 】(or 【*θw-】), see on 【vāj-】 ‘hold’, 【vāñ-】 ‘to toss’ and 【uysvāñätä】 ‘tosses up’, 【vāna-】 ‘dwelling place’|||[Skjærvø,II, p.125]

SVK: 【‘place, insert’ (Dict.)】 ||| This word is fictitious. For details see 【IF】, 86,1981 [1982], 212—222. 【ṣyanāña】 in Si 26.76 (155rl 【KT】 1.102) and 26.79 (155r5 【KT】 1.102) and 【sunāñą】 in Si 26.67 (153v4 【KT】 1.100) are scribal errors for 【pyanāña】, which is found in the same kinds of contexts. 【p】 and 【ṣ】 are graphically very similar and often confused even in well-written texts. [Emmerick, Ⅱ, p.147]
【‘to count’ (Dict.)】 ||| On LKh. 【ṣamāra-】 see above s.v. 【ṣṣavamāra-】, LKh. 【ṣamāra-】 ‘impenetrable darkness’. [Emmerick, Ⅱ, p.147]

SVK: 【‘sound, noise’ (Dict.) 】||| For the interpretation of the passage from the Rāma story quoted here (III 72.162) see s.v. 【nädo】 ‘burning’. [Emmerick, Ⅱ, p.147]

This word occurs in Si 26.55 (152rl 【KT】 1.98) only. Bailey renders 【ṣkāmakaña】 by ‘covering’ and also by ‘skin’. The meaning ‘skin’ he arrived at by misunderstanding Tibetan 【skyin-pa】 as somehow the equivalent of ‘【skyi-ba】 “outside of a skin”’. Bailey misunderstood Tibetan 【skyin-par】 ‘instead of’ also in Si 26.58: see above on 【bāje】 ‘together with’. [Emmerick, Ⅰ, p.120]

DKS: see 【naṣkūmāya】 (Ⅱ 60.29), possibly base 【skau-】 ‘to prepare, fit, ornament’.
rendering BS 【saṃskāra-】 and 【vyūha-】, see s.v. 【ṣkam-】 from *【skāmanka-】, fem. *【skāmaṅj̆ā-】.
‘staying’, Ⅱ 76.72 【eräkaña ṣṭāmä】, adjective 【-āma-】 to base present 【ṣṭa- (‹ his̆ta-)】, see s.v. 【ārra-】.
‘noise, twang’, Z 24.410 【durnānu ṣparggä】 ‘twang of bows’. Base 【sparg-, sprag-】, see s.v. 【haṣpalgy-】, to IE Pok. 996-7 O.Ind. 【sphūrjati】

SVK: 【‘pill’ (Dict.)】 ||| 【svakā-】 does not mean ‘pill’ but ‘suppository’. It corresponds in Si nine times to Skt. 【varti】 (19.4;  26.29, 30, 33, 37, 47,  49, 50, 51) and once to Skt. 【guḍikā】 (26.48). The corresponding Tibetan has 【ri-lu】 in all except two places (19.4, 5), where it has 【reṅ-bu】. [Emmerick, Ⅱ, p.147]

DKS: ‘they put on’; 【ṣvaudū】 ‘we put on’, preterite to 【ṣun-】.
‘he mounted’, Ⅲ 74.203 【ha'śa sa uska】 ‘he mounted high to the 【halsa】-tower’. See 【san-: sata-】.
‘saying’, ‘that’, introducing direct quotation, see 【se】, rendering BS 【iti】, see also Oss. 【zäygä】.
【saṃ, sä (ä for aṃ)】, older 【samu】 ‘just, precisely, only’, frequently 【sa khu, saṃ khu, samu kho】 ‘just as’. See 【samu】.

‘hair’, Manj. 63-4 【yaula śakṣa ttaira prrahauna jsīrrjau jsa āysū】 ‘ bad acts, hair on top of the head, dress adorned with trickeries’ (describing a 【rākṣasī】) here variant with 【ś-】 beside 【s-】; Manj. 35 (of a woman, 【strīya】)
SVK: Bailey’s 【sakṣa-】 ‘hair’ is in reality 【sakṣā-】 ‘appearance’. It is merely a Late Khotanese development of the Indian loanword found in Old Khotanese as 【sa(ṃ)ṭhāna-】, which corresponds to Tibetan 【cha-byad】 ‘external appearance, Buddhist Sanskrit 【veṣa】'. For details see 【The Khotanese śūraṅgamasamādhisūtra】, p. 81.  [Emmerick, Ⅰ, p.119]

SGS: ‘to be tainted’ I b act. tr./mid. intr. (= pass.) B ppp. 【saṃkhilsta-】[p.130]

SVK: On the derivation from *【sakana-】 see 【Lautgeschichte und Etymologie】, ed. M. Mayrhofer et al.,  Wiesbaden 1980, 172.  [Emmerick, Ⅱ, p.148]

SGS: sad- ‘to appear, seem’ V a act. intr. C ppp. 【sasta-】[p.130]

SVK: ‘【san-】 ‘to rise’, suppletive 【sarb-】, participle 【sata-】’ (Dict.). ||| The present stem 【san-】 was read by Bailey in Suv K 64r1 (【KT】 5.115) [Suv 12.23]. However, close inspection of the manuscript shows that instead of Bailey’s 【sanīndä】, we must read 【sa[r]b[ī]ndä】. The passage in question is 【graha sa[r]b[ī]ndä u nakṣatra u urmaysde u purra】 ‘planets arise, and asterisms and the sun and the moon’. The verb is an addition on the part of the Khot. translator and has no equivalent in the Skt. text. Note, however, e.g. 【sarbaṃdä urmaysde】 ‘the rising sun’ in Suv P 69r4 (【KT】 1.246) [Suv 3.64]. [Skjsærvø, Ⅱ, p.148]

DKS: 【sa, sama, samva】, older【 samu】 ‘precisely, just, only’, and often ‘but’. See 【sam-】.
‘be even, plain, accord, agree, be proper’

DKS: ‘precisely, fittingly, just, only; but’, 【samva, sama, samvī, samī, same】 (pronoun 【te】 ‘you’), 【saṃ, sä, sa, samuṃ】
SVK: ‘precisely, fittingly, just, only; but’ ||| A further instance of the LKh. spelling 【sa】 contrasts two clauses in 【LSt】 17ab 【thauña na na parye sa vara ṇesta ttye pa】 ‘he did not depart from the place, he just sat down there in front of her’. This 【sa】 was misunderstood as ‘he mounted’ (‹ 【sata-】 suppletive ppp. to 【sarb-】 ‘to rise’) by Bailey s.w. 【pa】 and 【byūka-】. [Maggi，Ⅲ，p.153]
