SVK: 【sāmalā hiye re】 ‘the vein of the shoulder’ in Si 21.5 (128v5 【KT】 1.60) does not correspond to the meaningless ‘BS 【saṃsthä-sirā-】 but to 【aṃsa- sthā sirā】 ‘the vein on the shoulder’ as pointed out in 【BSOAS】,XXXIV.l, 1971, 103-104 and XXXVII.3, 1974, 650. [Emmerick, I, 121]||| In fact, the correct rendering should be ‘the veins of the shoulders’. The only other occurrence of the word known to me is that listed by Bailey in 【Dict. s.v. sāmalā】 ‘shoulder’. In P 2893 #248-249 we find 【paijvā bąñā̜ñä audä svā̜milau vī bure】, which I take to mean ‘to be bound from the breasts as far as to the shoulders’, 【paijvā】 being locative of the source of motion, for which see Emmerick, ‘Syntax of the cases’, 33. Here 【svā̜milau】 can only be plural, which makes it clear that 【sāmalā】 in 【Si】 21.5 is likewise plural. [Emmerick, III, 153]

DKS: ‘month, 2nd month of the end of spring ( = 4th spring month)’

SVK: Bailey has extracted this ‘word’ from Si 20.11 (126v3 【KT】 1.56): ttye nā̜ma si biátä padimākä nā̜ma ‘its name is the so-called “eloquent- maker”’ (= Sanskrit 【etat sārasvataṃ nāma】, Tibetan 【miṅ ni Ice bde-bar byed-pa zhes bya-ste】). Here 【si】 is not part of the name but is the Khotanese word that functions like Sanskrit 【iti】 except that it directly precedes the word or words being quoted. The names of medicinal preparations and of diseases are regularly preceded in Si by the formula 【ttye nā̜ma si】. Thus, Si 13.41 (103r3—4 【KT】 1.38) has: 【ttye nā̜ma si, oṣṭagrīvakā u hvaṃno vī ūla-gīsārä *nā̜ma】 ‘its name is the so-called “【uṣṭragrīvaka】” and in Khotanese “camel-neck” by name’. See 【MSS】, 40, 1981, 32. [Emmerick, I, 121]

This 【sūrai】 was invented by Bailey on the basis of two passages: Mañj 13 【KBT】 113 and Mañj 66 【KBT】 116. In fact, 【sūrai】 is just the normal word for ‘clean, pure’: see 【Dict】. s. v. 【suraa-】 ‘clean’. [Emmerick, I, p.121]

This is rather a noun ‘fame’ and is a loanword from Sanskrit 【suṣṭuti】 ‘good praise’. It is attested in two passages only, 【haraysdai dīśi’vī sūṣṭa jasta-kṣīrvā bvari】 (Ch 0048.38—39 【KBT】 73) ‘his fame will extend in (all) directions as far as the realms of the gods.’ 【dyena cha bu’jsā suṣṭya. ttyau āysya pharāka kalpa】. ‘with (fine) appearance, (good) complexion, virtues, fame—adorned with those for many aeons’ in Suv 3.91 (P3513.73r2 【KT】 1.248) corresponds to Skt. 【rūpeṇa varṇena yaśena kīrtyā samalaṃkṛtā bhontu aneka-kalpān】 (ed. J. Nobel p. 42 lines 2—3). Thus 【suṣṭya】 corresponds to Skt. 【kīrtyā】 ‘fame’. [Emmerick, II, 150]

DKS: v 262 DR 0233 to read 【cu rro ja nase nātu īni tätä ne paśīdi】 ‘whatever shares I may have received, those they do not let go (send?)’. See s.v. 【nās-】.

SVK: For 【asadi-vīraa-】 in the Sudh passage quoted here see above s.v. *【vīraa-】 ‘hostile’. [II, p.150]

DKS: ‘month name, first month of the second winter season of two months each’

SGS: ‘to touch’ I d tr. B ppp. 【skuta-】|||3 sg. pres., O.Kh.: 【skote】 Z 13. 23; 19. 84; 【skaute】 Z 22. 144; 【skauye】 N 127. 11 = H 144 NS 32+NSB 1712 【KT】 5. 93 (?).|||3 sg. pf. tr. m., O.Kh.: 【skute】 Z 24. 194.|||3 sg. pf. tr. f., O.Kh.: skutātä Z 2. 56. [p.134]

SVK: 【stada̜】 is attested only in Si 24.21 (140v3 KT 1.80). It is evidently a scribal error for 【styāda̜】, ‘firm’. The writing of 【sta】 for 【styū】 may be due to the fact that after writing the 【me】 of 【hame】 the scribe’s eye was caught by the word 【mesta̜】, preceding 【hame】.|||【stada̜】 here corresponds to Sanskrit 【sthiraḥ】 ‘firm’ just as we find 【styūdä】 bañā̜ñä ‘to be bound firmly’ in Si 25.32 (144v4 KT 1.86) to correspond to Sanskrit 【bandhaḥ sthiraḥ】. The Tibetan has here 【sra-ba】 ‘hard, firm’, which is also found to render Sanskrit kathina ‘hard, firm’ (Si 9.5). Khotanese 【styūda-】 also renders Sanskrit 【kaṭhina, kāṭhinya】 (Si 13.38; 24.4; 25.4).|||[Emrick,II,p.150]

SGS: ‘to praise’ ? hybrid act. tr. A/B ppp. 【staväta】|||3 sg. opt., L.Kh.: 【stavī】 P 3513. 74r2 【KT】 1. 249 tr. 【stoṣyate】.|||3 pl. pres, act., L.Kh.: 【stavīdä】 Hed. 23. 16 【KT】 4. 36.|||3 pl. pf. tr., O.Kh.: 【stavätāndä】 Or 9609. *27V3 【KT】 1. 236 tr. 【stavito】.||| Et. Ir. has *【stav-】 as in Av. 【stav-】 ‘preisen’, ppp. °【stūta-】, but the ppp.is apparently due to the influence of BHS 【stavita-】 (on which see F. Edgerton, Grammar, p. 236). O.Ind. had 【stauti】, 【stuta-】. Cf. also MPe ‘【st】’【y- ‹ *stāvaya- 】(【Verbum】, p. 209); Parth. 【‘st’w-】 (Ghilain, p. 77); Man. Sogd. 【'psṯw-】 ‘disown’ ‹ * 【apa-stava-】 (BBB, p. 101 ad e20); Waxī 【stau-, staudi-】 ‘to praise’ (IIFL, ii. 541). See *【paṣṭu-】.|||[p.134]

‘constriction ’(Dict.)|||This word is attested also in Old Khotanese. It should be read instead of 【harbiśyau】 in FM 25,la2 【KT】 3.125. Bailey has there 【harbiśyau】in all editions, but my photograph reveals only 【haṃtharkyau】, which is
quite clear apart from the anusvāra. Read therefore: 【varä ṣṭānä ttītä dukhyau jsa ttänai byevīndä parrīyu haṃtharkyau haysgamatyau jsa】‘At once then they will obtain thereby deliverance from woes, oppressions,afflictions.’For 【haṃtharkyau haysgamatyau jsa】 cf. Suv 3.57(68r2—3【KT】1.246) 【haysgame jsa ... haṃtharkyau jsa.】|||[Emmerick,II, p.157]

SVK:
‘in itself, of itself’(Dict. 458a)|||Bailey interprets 【hame śuka】 etc. in 【Sudh】 A 114 【uttärye diśi’jsai paṣṭą̄ñi hame śuka】 = 【Sudh】 C 171 【uttarye dīśa jsa paṣṭaña hama śuka】 =【Sudh】 P 259-260 【uttarye dīśa’jsa paṣṭaña hamä śūkä】 as ‘himself alone’.The same interpretation is found in 【BSOAS】, XXIX.3, 1966, 512 and in【Dict】. 401 s.v. 【śśūka-】‘alone’. Degener, 【SII】, 11-12, 1986, 26 has shown that 【hame】 etc. is 3 sg. ind. mid. from 【häm-】 ‘to become, be’ (< OKh.【* hämäte】) and is an auxiliary to be connected with the preceding participle of necessity:‘He must set out alone from the northern region’. Similarly,she points out that 【hamai】 in 【JS】 l 9r1 (81) 【yāva khue rrāśa’yuḍāṃdä
hamai riṣa’yä】 is not a Late Khotanese form of 【hamata-】 ‘oneself’ (as Bailey, 【Dict.】 and Dresden,【JS】 433) but the 2 sg. pf. intr. of 【häm-】(<OKh.【*hämätī】):‘as soon as they set you free, you became a 【r˳ṣi’】|||[Maggi,III, p.164]

Under this heading Bailey quotes seven passages from the Si, two of which he translates and for six of which he cites the counterpart in the Tibetan version . It is striking that the Tibetan consistently has【hjam-ćam】, which cannot mean‘equal, of the same amount’.|||[Emmerick,I, p.126]

SVK: 【hūttarya】 in Mañj 109 【KBT】 118 is a misreading for 【hū ttada】 (see above s.v. 【*mvarye】). For 【hū ttada】 compare 【hū ttamdī】 in Rāma 255 【KT】 3.76.[Emmeric,III,170]

This huna is certainly = 【hūna】 ‘sleep’. For the juxtaposition of 【diḍā】 ‘indolence’ and 【hūna】 ‘sleep’ cf. Z 12.88 【ka bodhisatvä diḍete rrāṡu  hämāte dbāḍä hūśtä ärragāḍä hämäte 】‘if a Bodhisattva comes under the power of indolence (and) sleeps at an improper time, he is guilty’ (Emmerick). Thus【 KBT】 74 no. 22.58 【pūṣa paśara diḍā huna】 means ‘cast aside completely indolence (and) sleep’. Emmerick has given me the following from the Si: ‘For the connection of 【hūna-】 “sleep” with “indolence” note the use of ha̜nä in Si 14.21 (107v3 【KT】 1.46; misread hu̜ñä in 【KT】 1 ed. 1 and hu̜ñä KT 1 ed. 2) to render Sanskrit 【tandrā-】 and Tibetan 【sñom-pa】 “indolence”. In Si 1.24 (4) Tibetan【 sñom-pa】 corre- sponds to Sanskrit 【ālasya-】 and Khotanese dide (5vl KT 1.8).’|||The connection between 【didāti-】 and 【hūna-】 furnishes the key to understanding an unclear passage in Mañj: Mañj [68] [【KBT】 117.80; Emmerick, 【Studia iranica】, 6, 1977, 68) 【ysūrya jaḍa briya kīdeśa' cu ra ba hau dīḍāe hvāna】. This I believe means ‘Dveṣa, Moha, Rāga (are) kleśas, to whom (belong) weakness, indolence, sleep’. Here 【hvāna】 is written for 【hūna】, cf. Mañj [46] 【nūstuāra】 for 【nūstūra】, and Mañj 245 【abvātta】 for 【abūtta 】(Skt 【abhūta】), see s. v. 【abvātta】 (Emmerick). For 【ba hau】 ‘little power’ see Emmerick, Studia iranica, 6, 1977, 74, and for【 dira-】 ‘weak’ Emmerick, JRAS, 1969, 64f.|||For the connection of ‘sleep, indolence, torpidity, etc.’ with the 【kleśas】 in general see 【Hôbôgirin】 p.123a.[Skjærvø,I,129]

【humari】 in P 2893.171 【KT】 3.89 is not a unique word meaning ‘shoulder’ but a variant spelling of the common word hamari meaning ‘joints’ (see above s. v.【 hamara-】 ‘limb’). Actually the scribe probably intended to write hamari. The 【-u-】 is merely a downstroke, perhaps a slip of the pen. It does not usually have this form. For a correctly-written 【hu】 compare 【huṣka】 in line 180.[Emmerick,I,130]

In 【Indologica Taurinensia】, VIII—IX, 1980—1981, 17 Bailey specu¬lates further concerning words discussed in 【Diet. s.v. humo】.
The meaning of 【humo】 is unknown. It occurs in Z 21.27 only: 【hevira dasta kye ssu humo ttone väta "hevira】 are her hands which indeed were (once) 【humo】 and oily’. Both 【hevira】 and 【humo】 are 【hapax】 legomena about whose meanings it is possible only to speculate. It is not even known whether humo is an aw-stem or whether it contains 【u】 ‘and’ contracted with 【*huma】 or 【*hume】.[Emmerick，II，172]

SVK: 【huṣv-】 is found only in Late Khotanese and derives, as Bailey says at the head of the article, ‘from 【huṣṣ-】 “grow”’. This seems to me to be incompatible with Bailey’s comment at the end of the article: ‘from *【uxšnu-’】.|||All the forms quoted unter 【huṣv-】 show 【a】 secondary 【v】 except two: ‘3 sing, 【huṣute】' and ‘noun in 【-ti-】, Sid. 121vl 【huṣuttye jsa'】. According to Bailey 【huṣuttye jsa】means ‘for the most part’. This makes no sense in the context and is not supported by either the Sanskrit or the Tibetan. In fact the relevant part of Si 19.1 (121vl—2 【KT】 1.48) reads: 【paḍam khāysā̜ña ṣṭukä āphīḍe. huṣu ttye jsa. samna̜, hauṣḍe.】 ‘the wind residing in the receptacle of (digested) food (【pakvāśaye】) has been disturbed (【kruddhaḥ】) (and) has increased (【balī】) (and) the excrement (【viṭ-】) is dried up (【śoṣa-】) by it’. Thus, 【huṣu = huṣā】 3 sg. pf. intr. m. (see SGS 154). It corresponds to Sanskrit ball ‘powerful’ and to Tibetan 【śas che-bar gyur-pas 】‘having become predominant’.|||【huṣute】 in Si 14.21 (107v2 【KT】 1.46) is to be read 【huṣuve】, but the interpretation is not affected, 【ttaraṃdarū-v-ai dai huṣuve】 ‘his body fire has increased’. On vai, which Bailey explains here as ‘【= vaskai】’, see above s. v. 【vai. huṣuve】 corresponds to Old Khotanese 【huṣātä】.|||For Late Khotanese 【u】 = Old Khotanese 【ā】 see my article on ‘The vowel phonemes of Khotanese’ in 【Studies in diachronic, synchronic, and typological linguistics, Festschrift for Oswald Szemerényi】, ed. B. Bro- gyanyi, Amsterdam 1979, especially pp. 245, 249.[Emmerick,II,130]

SVK: 【haiga】 is merely a LKh. spelling of OKh. 【hulga】 as pointed out by me in the 【Szemerényi】 【Fs】. 249-250 n. 7. It is not in principle any different from spellings such as 【pvais-】 for 【puls-】 ‘to ask’ except that in such cases 【-v-】 is found in words beginning with a labial. Hence Bailey’s explanation of 【haiga】 as from ‘*【hīnaka-】 from 【hai-: hi-】 “to bind”’, as in 【SDTV】 1.30 is untenable.[Emmerick,III,176]

DKS: ‘see pūheitä ‘it is tied’, see hai-'.hi- ‘to bind’’

SVK:
As usual it is unsafe to invent new words for the sake of unclear contexts, 【ttaudä herä】 in P 2891.15—16 【KT】 3.79 is likely to mean ‘warm moisture’ in the light of Si 25.3 (142r2 KT 1.82), where 【ttaudai vā hera ysautta̜】, probably means ‘warm (【uṣṇa-】) moisture flows out (【srāva-】)’ corresponding to Tibetan 【hjag-pa ćha-ba】 ‘warm discharge (【uṣṇa-srāva-】)’. Theoretically hera could be simply the usual word for ‘thing’ (【Dict】. s.v. 【hära】), but the resulting translation ‘a warm thing flows out (of the wound)’ shows that this is not compelling. Moreover, 【hera】 ‘moisture’ recalls the Khotanese verb 【paher-】 ‘to moisten’, which in Si 26.36 (149v3 【KT】 1.94) corresponds to Sanskrit 【bhāvitam】 ‘steeped’ and Tibetan 【sbaṅ】 ‘steeped, soaked’.
[Emmerick,II,173]

In 【KT】 6.429 Bailey proposed to derive this word from IE *【sāg~】. In the 【Dict】, he offers a new etymology from the ‘base 【ad-】 “speak” ’. Both etymologies suffer from the disadvantage that no close Iranian cognate lends support. Moreover, the phonological developments postulated disguise all relation with the assumed bases.
The clue to the etymology of 【ho】 is given by Chorasmian 【š’w’c】 ‘voice’, which W.B. Henning connected with Avestan 【frauuāka-】 ‘speech’ already in 1956 (Acta Iraniea, 15, 497). Derivation of ho from 【*fravāka-】is straightforward: cf. 【hor-】 ‘to give’ ‹ 【*fra-bara-】 and【 haṃdrauysia-】 ‘flying through the air’ ‹ 【*antara-vāzika-】, cf. Parthian 【’ndrw’z】.[Emmerick,II,173]

KBM_MBhP: n. ‘inequality; repugnance’不平；厌恶，反感〔按〕Emmerick译作 “不平等，离平等”。依据汉译的上下语境，即“见一众生于已有违，心缘于此，不生爱念”，此处涉及的是此经倡导 的某种修行意念。“不平”是 这个于闻语汇的本来意义，但此处明显可看出，此语汇另有表示心境的含义，应表示“厌恶，反感”。故而增添词义。

XJM: n. skt. āmātya〔古〕‘阿摩支"、 ‘宰相’
n. 古音译‘伊里桑宜、伊里丧宜’，证人。
n. ‘起贤’，屋悉贵的法师，买主。
n. ‘惬悉具’，杜弥萨劳族落人，债权人
n. ‘乞米加达陀’，曾经以Ṣau官身份出现在和田博物馆藏的一件文书上 (Emmerick 1984, 194-195 ; Studies 3, 46), 但未见拥有执政纪年。《卖女》案发生时， 以Ṣau官身份拥有当政纪年。
n. ‘仲隅李’，证人。互见于《卖女》、 《典水》案。
n.地名，音译‘杜弥萨劳’。派生词：【Dumesalą̄na-】‘杜弥萨劳族落，杜 弥萨劳村’
n.地名，古代于阗六城之一。派生词：【Pa’ja-】‘Pa’（帕）城的’
n. 来自skt. 【puṇyadatta】‘功德赐’，古译‘裴捺’，尉迟伏师9年，岀2000 文购买一女子。曾是王室的奴仆，马主的儿子。
n. ‘不达米’，似来自skt. 【puṇyadharma-】,意译‘福法’。典押水案的参与者。
n. 来自skt.复合词【puṇya+udaka】‘功德水’。互见于《卖女》、《典水》案， 作为证人、保人。
n. ‘布儿萨’，拔伽城的探子之一。
n. ‘保达’。阴性人名。《舅卖甥女》案被卖女子的母亲或者舅母。
n.地名，‘保诺罗族落’。《舅卖甥女》案卖方所居住的地方。

XJM_text: 派生词：①@Phamnāj5na- 或者 phamnāj^ña-, “潘野聚落的”。阴性单数具/从格： pharnnājQñi āsemji jsa"从潘野聚落的湖” Yb#2, Yc#3

XJM: 派生词，‘潘野的’。参阅【XJM】第 122 页。

XJM_text: f.instr./abl.sg.|||%Or.9268a Yb#2;Yc#3  【Phaṃnāją̄ñi āṣeṃji jsa】‘从潘野聚落的湖’

XJM: n. ‘勃罗’，破沙。《典水》案的举债方之一。
派生词，‘拔伽的，隶属拔伽的’。
n. ‘勃朗宜李’，《典水》案的举债方之一
n. ‘勃罗南迪’，证人。又依据《尉迟 曜11年裴捺卖地》之封函（段晴2012, 128）,此人来自克舍罗村，是思略的父亲
n. ‘莫劳衷’，证人，拔伽城的探子。
XJM_text: %BH5-2 J3#6, J4#10|||%Or.9268a Yb#11 复数属格，或者附加了词缀ana-的复数第 一格 【malārrjųnām】 ‘莫劳衷家族’

XJM: n. 《卖女》的买主，‘曼萨’，【puñadattä】‘裴捺’的别名。详见【XJM】第103页。
n.《高僧买奴》的证人，破沙，他又叫做māmsali ‘萨李’
n. ‘遥居力’，《典水》案的主角，出钱者。 他来自潘野。
n. ‘耶舍罗’。《卖女》、《蠲除》的书吏。
不确定读出。伏阇达五年时的 ṣṣau官，国王的近臣。
n. 源自skt.复合词 vikrāṃta < vikrānta ‘勇猛，勇敢’, datta < 过去分词 datta ‘所赐，所授’。意译名‘勇赐’，官居破沙。此人互见于《卖女》、《蠲除》以及 《典水》等三件封函。
n. 来自skt.复合词【vidyākānta】, 意译“明艳”。《卖女》案被出卖者
n. 来自skt.复合词 【vimala + arjuna】,意译“无垢阿周那”，音译“勿摩罗竺”，证人。
n. 古译‘伏阇璥’，于阗王， 692—716年在位。《买奴》案发生在此王第 4年，参阅【XJM】第105页。
n. 古译‘伏阇达’，于阗王，约公元628年继位，统治时间不长。
n. 来自skt.复合词，viṣṇa < viṣṇu ‘毗湿奴’；caṃdrä < candra-‘月亮’。音译作‘毗湿纳詹得利’。摄国者。
n. ‘维萨李’，官位萨波。《舅卖甥女》封函上留有他的印章。
n. ‘尚杰罗',应是复数属/为格或者加了【-āna-】词缀的变化形态，表示家族属性。
n. ‘瑟尼洛吉’，于阗语文献中常见人名。《蠲除》、《卖女》两案的证人。
n. 古译‘瑟尼洛’，于阗语文献常见人名，《蠲除》、《典水》案的探子，来自拔 伽。
n. ‘桑宜德’，证人。似来自skt.复合词saṅgha + datta意译‘僧伽赐’。
n. ‘桑宜南迪’，似来自skt.复合词saṅgha + nanda,意译‘僧喜’。伏阇达5年时任拔伽的探子。
n. ‘桑宜如力’，skt.复合词saṅgha + śūra,意译‘僧雄’。《典水》案中举债方一员。
n. 来自skt. 【sucandra-】,意译‘妙月’， 证人。
n. 来自skt. 【somacandra-】,意译 ‘苏摩月’，证人。
n. 来自skt. 【suvarman】,意译‘妙铠’， ‘妙胄’。作为探子、证人互见于《蠲除》、 《卖女》案。
n. 似来自skt. 【suvidatta】。音译加意译‘悉万赐’，《典水》的证人，来自帕 (pa’)城。
n. 音译‘悉禾’。杰谢乡吏、破沙，《买奴》案的监理者。
n. 音译‘悉万竹’，ṣṣau 官。
n. 音译‘亨举’，贺悉具布的儿子。被典押给怄悉具，并死在那里。
n. 音译‘贺悉具布’。互见于《买 奴》、《蠲除》案，但前者发生在杰谢，后者发生在拔伽。似应是两个同名人。他是《买奴》案的证人，《蠲除》案的主角，将 儿子亨举抵押，因儿子亡故而获得1000 文。
adj.‘无赊欠的’，参阅词语注释部分，XJM 第110页。
n.‘马主之子’，参阅词语注释部分，XJM第111页。
Pkt.<Skt.【āmātya】‘宰臣，阿摩支’，参阅词语注释部分，XJM第89页。
XJM_text: %BH5-l F3#1【āmācū】<【āmācӓ+-ū】（代词第二人称复数附黏着式形式）

XJM: adj.‘……乡的，……城的’。 n.‘……城居民，……乡居民’。参阅【auva-】【auya-】。
<Skt.【ācārya】‘法师’。于阗寺院的高僧才获此头衔。

< 【umānu】,第二人称代词复数的属/为格。

‘涉及买卖的’。后词【-vāḍa-】的词源不详。贝利译作，‘document’(Dict.3 82)
n.‘伤口，破损’。应从动词【guhad-】‘to harm wound’(SGS, 30) 所构成的名词。
n.‘天神，天’，此词用来翻译梵文的deva‘天，天神’，如梵文deva的用法，也用来称呼国王。
v.‘结清，还上’，特指‘清算利息’。参阅XJM第77页。

n.‘烧伤，烫伤’。似是源自于阗语动词【ttav-】‘灼热’，该词与梵语的【tap-】‘热，烫，烤’同源（SGS,38)。
adv.‘又，即，然后’。来自早期于阗语的【ttīyӓ】。
